title: The Mitchells vs the Machines

reviews.content: A robot uprising of the humorous kind, The Mitchells vs the Machines came at me from behind and got its hooks in. A Netflix animated flick I had no interest in (my 11 year-old felt differently) and ended up fully in its embrace. The father-daughter storyline is handled with care even azs the Mitchell clan is hunted by robots and giant Furbys (you read that right). The animation's vivid and the characters well-drawn (no pun intended) while the sentiment is heartfelt. Lord and Miller are becoming household names they've been killing it.

reviews.review_title: Puts almost every other recent animated film to shame in ambition and execution
reviews.content: No amount of behind-the-scenes cinematic team-ups in recent years can compare to the overwhelming power that the guys behind Gravity Falls (Michael Rianda and Jeff Rowe) and Spider-Verse (Phil Lord and Chris Miller) have when you put their creative minds together on a singular project.This is an amazingly fun movie from start to finish, benefited by some brilliantly stylized CGI that continues the trend that Spider-Verse started but taken a few steps further with some added medium blending that very much blew my mind. It also helps that 92% of the jokes land right on target. Did I mention that it also has a disarmingly astute emotional core?Honestly, at this rate Sony Pictures Animation may be beating Disney and Pixar at their own game.
This animation is really good. It's fun, vibrant, lively, and it's really relevant to modern lives. I really enjoyed the references to social media addiction.

My daughters and I watch a movie every Saturday night before they go to bed, and we usually just pick one and I cross my fingers that I won't be miserable for 2 hours. This movie was an absolute PLEASANT surprise. Great modern story, great adult humor, and AMAZING animation. A great family movie that will keep you laughing and entertained the entire time. I didn't watch the trailer and I didn't even know who did the voices in it. Watch this movie, with or without kids, it's a great watch.

reviews.review_title: Innovative Experiment of a Family Road Film
reviews.content: Sony Pictures Animation has been growing further and further in their filmography by experimenting with fresh computer technology and innovative stories, and none could be better proof than their most recent feature, The Mitchells vs. The Machines. Co-written and directed by former Gravity Falls writer Mike Rianda, the film was initially set to come out in September of 2020, but due to COVID restrictions, it was eventually delayed until the end of April and released on Netflix. Now that the world is finally ready to see the Mitchells unleashed, just how much was the wait worth it in the end?The film follows the Mitchells, a dysfunctional family with an aspiring filmmaker daughter named Katie and a down to earth father named Rick that fail to see eye to eye from when they were younger. While attempting to rekindle their relationship on Katie's trip to college, the whole family winds up having to save Earth from a robot uprising while on a road trip. Now based on that bizarre premise, it would seem like we have a case of two different movies clashing together. However, the otherwise routine storyline of a family overcoming their differences is ultimately saved and even elevated by this other arc, because the movie's biggest theme lies in how overly dependent people have become to technology nowadays. While it is wonderful just how much the world has advanced in adapting to technological innovation, including animated features, one must be careful to not take it for granted. Sometimes, all it takes is just one person to deem an AI obsolete for the whole world to fall under chaos; that is just how much the reliance on technology has grown in humanity, both for better and worse.As for the Mitchells story arc, like I mentioned before, it is admittedly a fairly standard plot about a parent and offspring needing to overcome their differences to connect again. However, to the film's credit, the characters themselves range from charmingly hysterical to surprisingly relatable. Katie represents the adorkably creative artist in many of today's generation, Rick is a good hearted albeit overly indulgent maniac of a dad trying to figure out today's youth, Linda is an overly perfectionist mother that demands the family be functional even at her most calm, and Katie's little brother Aaron might be the most hilarious dinosaur obsessed squirt since Calvin from Calvin & Hobbes (and their bug eyed potato dog Monchi is the cherry on top). This whole family of eccentric weirdos drive the film forward, especially compared to their allies and enemies, be it evil robots or family rivals. Not to mention, the whole cast clearly had a blast in their roles, especially Abbi Jacobson and Danny McBride being the most authentic as a quirky albeit frustrated teen and an overly impulsive father.Out of all the animated features to be released this year right now, this film might have the most unique visuals and art direction yet. In addition to Lindsey Olivares' stylized character designs translating seamlessly in the SPA renderfarm, the animators did the most in exercising their acting chops to make the characters move like real people yet still feel appropriately exaggerated. The backgrounds are also a neat reflection of how the United States would look if it went from a neat colorful environment to a post apocalyptic sci-fi nightmare, with the right amount of special effects, color gradients and shadows to go along with the world-building. There are even nice additional 2D animated chunks that are either used in lieu of exposition or cute little add ons to the suspense in a given scene. The only genuine criticism to give the visuals is that sometimes those gimmicky effects and filters can be a little too frequent and even jarring, especially when some of the movie's humor is overly reliant on modern internet culture. Let's just say some of the filters could come off as jump scares.I can't think of a better energetic romp of a film for the whole family to enjoy as much as this one. Not only is The Mitchells vs. The Machines an eye-catching twist on the family road dramedy genre, but it might be the most fun animated film released in a while. If Netflix and Sony Pictures Animation keep up this track record of enjoyable thrill rides disguised as innovative experiments, then there's no telling what the future holds for moviegoers. If you haven't seen the film yet, go on your Netflix account and give it a go. There's never been a better time to connect with your love of movies than now.
Loved every minute of it. Fantastic story and animation. Recommended!

A distillation of 'of-the-moment' touch points so calculated and desperate it felt like robots had constructed it to please their masters, or worse a boardroom of executives had conducted a series of audience surveys and presented this as the result. I'm saying it had the appearance of depth and humanity while lacked real human depth and insight.It was so jammed with whizz and bang and approximations of human moments that it fooled itself that it had heart, when it was merely imitating it.It finished as less than the sum of its parts, without meaning and just mediumly entertaining.

reviews.review_title: so this is what gets 8/10 these days
reviews.content: The most mediocre and boardroom-designed bunch of "typical American family" characters, including a pseudo-lesbian teenage daughter, live in your typical "my family spends too much time staring at their phones" world when suddenly a suspiciously Apple-like company does something evil and thus ROBOTS TAKE OVER THE WORLD.Yawn.So they must battle robots and get to the mall so they can win and the movie ends.This. THIS insult to human intelligence has a higher rating than Lilo & Stich, Ice Age, Isle Of Dogs, Big Hero, Toy Story 2, no, no THE MITCHELLS VERSUS THE MACHINES is such a masterpiece of mediocrity that THIS is what is considered a great film today.My vote: 6/10 if you reeeeally are desperate for some animation. Although that would require some sense of quality.

Many a true word said in jest in this jest packed production that successfully parodies a host of familial, social and technological scenarios and nails them with aplomb. You'll recognise something in all the characters that you're familiar with in the analogue, some traits a little closer to home than you might like, but take it on the chin, smile and embrace what you really can be - before it's too late and the machines try and take it from you.

I really enjoyed this film and laughed really hard my diaphragm hurt. It was a really well told story and the animation style reminded me of the Into the spider verse style but with its own twist.The jokes were on point as well, the humour had its own unique quirky feel which once you are in on the joke just brings along for the ride.Totally worth a watch for everybody it's just a great family film for everyone with something for all to enjoy.

I knew nothing about this movie before watching it. You can quibble about how some of the plot elements or characters are derivative, but overall it is a good watch. Funny and visually great, with some well-designed action sequences as well.Good for a family night viewing.

reviews.review_title: Good animation, funny bits, and some heart, but with a sub-par story :-(
reviews.content: Not a classic :-(. I also did not like the adult voice casting for the young boy :-(

reviews.review_title: Flashy but couldnt get into it.
reviews.content: 2 out of 5 stars.The Mitchells vs. The Machines is a dull animated comedy film that tries to be flashy and fun with its direction. Like how Spider Man into the Spider verse was. But the story was dull. The humor is forgettable. The voice cast was tedious. I just had trouble trying to get into it. Sure kids will find it enjoyable.

A sunny Thursday morning, a Sony producer comes in and says: "Hey, let's create a new animated movie for cash! We'll use standard family movie script No 6, we'll praise being weird and mediocre family, sprinkle some compassion, etc. Then we'll mix some modern theme like computers overtaking the world. We'll speed-up the images x3 so all the ADHD kids can't die of boredom, add a lot of slow-mo, so parents can keep up and voilla!"

The Mitchells are a fairly typical, if slightly dysfunctional, family. Daughter Katie is a bit of an outsider at her school but is looking forward to attending film school in California... thousands of miles from her family. After an argument her father unilaterally decides that rather than have Katie take the plane as planned, the whole family will drive across the country together. Katie is unimpressed but soon she, her parents, her dinosaur obsessed brother and their pug are on their way. Shortly after they set off news comes thorough of a major technological advance; cell phones will soon be defunct; replaced by robots. As soon as the designer announced this the robots rebel and start capturing all humans. Only the Mitchells remain free; it will be up to them to save humanity!I really enjoyed this animated film; there were plenty of laughs from start to finish as well as child friendly thrilling moments and mild scares. It might not be as philosophically deep as Pixar films but it still had something to say about family without being mawkish. It didn't over use pop culture references, and those that there were, such as the nods to 'Kill Bill' were subtle enough that those who don't get them won't be thinking they've missed something. The animation is impressive with good character designs and the voice cast do a fine job throughout. Overall I'd certainly recommend this; it is a lot of fun and suitable for all ages.

The Mitchells are a quirky family. Daughter Katie Mitchell (Abbi Jacobson) is an aspiring filmmaker but her classmates ridicule her. She is accepted into film school and finds her own tribe. She is eager to leave home but her father (Danny McBride) fears letting her go. He refunds her plane ticket and takes the family on a cross country road trip to her school. Mother (Maya Rudolph) tries to keep the peace while dino-obsessed little brother is dragged along. It's not the end of the world or is it? Unbeknownst to them, the launch of a new phone AI is leading to the machine apocalypse.This is written and directed by Michael Rianda and Jeff Rowe. Their most prominent previous work is writing for Gravity Falls. This has a lot of that show's sensibilities and I love it. I love the animation styles. I love the family. It's a quirky family. It's a quirky family with a wild outrageous world-ending apocalypse and it's fun. My only complaint is that this may be a bit too long. Of course, I would look to add another scene with the Poseys. It would be great to have the Poseys return to cower in the gas station and telling the Mitchells to hide. It would be the inflection point and a call to arms moment. As it stands, the father acquiesces to his daughter. If the Poseys come back, little Aaron could gain confidence to be heroic. Mother Linda can strive to show her family's worth and father would still be the last to join. It would work better with a better catalyst. All in all, this is a fun movie and everybody should watch it. Afterwards, you can binge Gravity Falls.

'The Mitchells Vs The Machines (2021)' is an energetic, mile-a-minute family drama from producers Phil Lord and Chris Miller (whose work includes '21 Jump Street (2012)', 'The Lego Movie (2014)' and 'Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse (2018)') that aims to prove that Sony Pictures Animation isn't just a one-trick pony (the aforementioned web-slinging surprise hit). It's definitely hyperactive, playing with 'internet culture' in a way that almost confirms stereotypes about modern day reduced attention spans. It doesn't dampen the experience, though; it just means that you have to adjust to its quick, almost unforgiving pace. Having said that, the story itself is actually rather slow to get going (it feels often unrelenting in the moment because there is often so much stuff packed into so little space). It's also a tad long on the whole and is, generally speaking, really predictable. These issues don't mean that the movie isn't entertaining, though. It's rather fun when it gets going and its characters feel relatively rounded. There are a handful of exciting set-pieces and the jokes land more often than they flop (though there are some cringe-worthy moments, for sure). The thing is also beautiful from a technical point of view. It's animation is lively, believable and full of joy. Actually watching the picture is enjoyable in and of itself. Overall, it's a solid animated effort with just about the right balance of humour and heart. 7/10.

reviews.review_title: Starts off mechanical, but it ramps up by the end
reviews.content: The Mitchells vs the Machines starts off pretty mechanically. There's a kid who doesn't fit in (as usual), with quirky family members (seen it), and she's getting ready to go off to college (been there). But then, as it progresses, this movie transforms into something unique, and it managed to pleasantly surprise me a few times. It takes a while to ramp up, but I was really enjoying the story by the end.

Only thing ordinary of this movie are the generic storyline and themes. Other than that this movie is so gorgeously animated with the unique style, character design, voice acting and nice touch of comedy. From the makers of Spiderverse, this movie's bloated runtime feels like a treat. You can see the love they put into it. Watch it with your family, its totally worth it.

reviews.review_title: lol this is what aging corporate TV execs think kids want
reviews.content: Just be "wacky" and show smartphones and Instagram and pause time and put cringey filters and gifs over people's faces. Maybe reference a few semi-viral YouTube videos that noone's seen.When someone says "soulless corporate product" I see pretty much this. Whoever wrote it had a fun idea, whoever did the animation was talented - but the overall product stinks of out of touch Netflix corporation.

It's full of clichés, stereotypes and plain jokes. Closer to the end the number of cringy moments raises to one every minute. Music choice is also questionable at best.Should be fine for small kids, but I'd not recommend for adults.
This was hard to watch- it's ridiculously cringe and predictable. Not sure how it got a rating of 8!!

reviews.review_title: A must-see animated, action-pacted, comedic film complete with robots, evil smart phones and one crazy family adventure
reviews.content: The Mitchells vs. The Machines is a must-see animated, action packed, comedic film! It's complete with robots, evil smartphones and one crazy unexpected family adventure to save planet Earth. The fight scenes and special effects are literally out of this world.The storyline follows protagonist Katie Mitchell (Abbi Jacobson), a creative outsider who is looking forward to meeting "her people" at her new film school. Her dad, who just wants to keep his family together, decides to go on a cross-country road trip to take her there instead of Katie flying, so they can bond one last time. On the way, the family ends up in the middle of a robot uprising and now it's up to the Mitchells to work together to save the world.The main characters in this film are Katie, her dad Rick (Danny McBride), little brother Aaron (Michael Rianda), mom Linda (Maya Rudolph) and family dog Monchi (Doug the Pug). This film is all about connecting. Its director, Michael Rianda, uses every part of the creative process to make sure the audience relates to the characters. The storyline and the Mitchell's road trip are based on a real road trip some of the staff took while not using cell phones and just connecting. I love how the film combines both an illustrative, hand-painted approach and realism animation style to help develop the characters. Rianda helped develop Katie's character by making her love for filmmaking a focal point throughout the movie. There are hilarious freeze-frame moments where Katie is writing on a screen, it's almost as if she is the narrator. One of my favorite scenes is when Linda turns into a "super" mom and takes on the robots to try to protect her kids. I also like that Rick and Katie's family song "Live Your Life" by T. I. and featuring Rihanna is used to represent their relationship and wrap up the theme of the movie.The message of this film is that everyone in a family has their own personality and you should just let people be themselves and focus more on understanding and connecting to them. In this film, Katie is considered a "weirdo" because she isn't like everyone else. The film shows how you should embrace your "weird" qualities, because that's what makes you unique.I rate The Mitchells vs. The Machines 5 out of 5 stars and recommend it for ages 8 to 18, plus adults. It releases April 30, 2021 on Netflix. Reviewed by Tiana S., KIDS FIRST!

You may not poke at your phone or rather hammer on it as hard you currently you are doing ... maybe even right now. A really fun and yet quite current themed movie. The fear of machines going against us, their inventors ... it is quite big.That being said, I didn't even know this movie existed. I found it by accident and not even on Netflix first, but on another streaming service. Was surprised as the logo and that sound we all know (and maybe love?) came on at the top of the movie. Now some say that they produce so many movies and many are subpar ... you can't say that in this instance.The story is good, the characters are great ... one may even say this has Pixar like quality ... and I wouldn't totally disagree with that ... at all. Funny, suspensful and really topical ... and tone wise hits all the right notes. I can only recommend this as much as I can.

I absolutely loved monchi the pug and the pal robots conversations. The story plot was hilarious and gave a funny take on an invasion on an otherwise serious situation. The voice acting was Brilliant, the relationship between the family members was very realistic in my opinion. I hope there's a sequel.

reviews.review_title: Movie to watch with the family
reviews.content: An epic sci-fi family adventure with few conventional elements, it actually has everything from a pleasantly sweet emotional tone coupled with wacky humor to a pile of hilarious action sequences and not to mention explosively gratifying animation, it ends up offering something for everyone. It does not forget the good of spending time with those we love as well as it helps parents accept that the children may move away at some point, guaranteeing that when you finish watching the movie you take a look at your family and thus find a treasure. An extraordinary film with extraordinary characters and one of the best productions of the year.

reviews.review_title: One of the best animated movies I've ever seen
reviews.content: I was genuinely shocked at how good this film was. The title seemed a bit silly and Sony Pictures Animation has a mixed record so I wasn't expecting much. Every aspect of the film is done perfectly - the characters are memorable, the moments are relatable, the action is rousing, the animation is stunning, the designs are sleek, the mix of visual styles is entertaining, the generational conflict is amusing and the humour is on point. In a complete 180 from The Emoji Movie, the treatment of social media, memes and technology is very up-to-date and clearly done by millennials who actually understand the topic. In the same way that Into the Spiderverse felt like a traditional comic come to life, this film felt like a Buzzfeed webcomic come to life. There are messages about family acceptance and human connection that go beyond the banal "phone bad" lectures of previous boomer flicks. This film is a masterpiece of the 2020s and of the millennial generation.

It wasn't all that great and certainly does not merit the 10/10 which gets to the point why? Would it have scored as high if Sony did not give it to Netflix? I don think it would it appears people vote everything up that is on Netflix for the sake of it. Then there is is the ones that have voted almost every terrible movie up because they are stuck at home during the pandemic. Why do people need to ruin review sites with fake 10s and fake 1s.

Perhaps my sense of humor is not keeping up with the times but I did not find this movie funny in the least. A nonsensical plot (yes, even for an animated film) slapped together with a bunch of idiots, throw them in a plot armor bender and you'll get this. This movie has absolutely nothing on most pixar and dreamworks movies so I'd suggest sticking to those.

The Mitchell's Vs The MachinesWhere to start on this disaster, so much was wrong, terrible animation, over wordy, awful characterisation.Who on earth thought a cartoon about a dysfunctional family would be worth watching, and then overlay this with contemporary snowflake anxieties.The script was clearly created by a committee.I hated it 2 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: The meme culture jokes are already outdated
reviews.content: Hooo boy, this is a strange one. There are unusually positive reviews saying 10/10 movie of the year, and it makes me wonder if we saw the same movie or are they bots?You see, the problem with making a movie based on 'trends' is that by the time the movie comes out, the jokes are already old. This movie is so forgettable, I forgot it's name like 3 times, and I already forgot most of the story, it was so bland.Did they rip off Pig the Pug?I'm a fan of the creators and producers (Gravity Falls and Spider-verse alumni) so I don't understand why this movie didn't hit the right notes with me, I wanted to like it.
The movie is a rippa!!!But let me be completely honest...its all about the dog.The best dog/pig/loaf of bread I've seen for years.Tremendous fun.Highly recommended :)

The unique comic book style is great, but I can't give it a higher review because the humor is so grating. The jokes in this animation are basically weird/nonsensical = funny. Nty. The main character is unlikable-she reminded me too much of the self-labeled quirky people I've met, even down to the messy unhygienic look. The "quirky" personality and aesthetic just screams "I'm trying too hard to show I'm not like other people" and my family found the movie to ultimately be a cringefest. Those that share my preferences probably won't enjoy this movie as much.

reviews.review_title: A Family-Friendly Fare Marred By Its Hyper Execution
reviews.content: From the creative force that brought you The Lego Movie & Into the Spider-Verse comes an original, imaginative & wholehearted delight concerning a dysfunctional family that finds its connective roots in the wake of a robot uprising. The Mitchells vs. The Machines is hilarious & heartfelt when it strikes the right notes but it's also overstuffed & overwritten to the point of annoyance.Co-written & directed by Mike Rianda in what's his feature directorial debut, the film employs a quirky animation style with a premise that promises plenty of fun & thrills but it's way too hyperactive for its own good. Rianda stuffs the story with everything he could think of. The comedic scenes are a hit or miss but feel like an onslaught at all times. And its dramatic moments don't pack a strong enough emotional punch to stick the landing.Unbridled energy is beneficiary but only if it is directed in the right direction. Here, it is all over the place with no one to keep a check on the overdose level. The themes & representation are done well but the narrative did need some brakes to not come off as trying too hard to be funny. There are times when it gets the combination right and those moments deliver the desired impact. And there's a lot more of that buried beneath all the suffocating glitter & filters.Overall, The Mitchells vs. The Machines is an unnecessary exercise in excess, and just a touch of restraint would've gone a long way in making it enjoyable & amusing for viewers of all ages & spectrums. Nevertheless, for a family-friendly fare, it offers a sufficiently entertaining extravaganza with good, hearty dose of laughs & fun. But there was also room for improvement here. And all it had to do was to slow down & trim out all that it could've done without. Not as impressive as it is made out to be.

reviews.review_title: It tried.. a little too hard
reviews.content:
This would have been a wonderful family film if only it wasn't trying so hard to be funny (and failing)
The forced in memes and full on trying to be quirky ruins the moment every 5 minutes.I feel it was supposed to be a game that didn't quite get the ratings and they didn't want to scrap the story so just handed it off to Netflix to turn in to a film.

The Mitchells vs the Machines is a good,entertaining family movie with a good message. The plot isnt anything too original but has nice modern cartoon vibe and the drawings are nice add. A nice movie to spend the time with family, but the fighting scenes might be too much for smaller kids.

...but only kinda.I can't deny that I really enjoyed the energetic animation and visual splendor. However, the writing was very dull and unspecial.The animation tries it's best to overcompensate for the lackluster script,
but it feels so incredibly disingenuous almost every time these characters speak. They are mostly portrayed as over the top caricatures, with "#relatable" human issues. But with the exception of the main character, the Mitchel family's humanity doesn't really shine through until the end. Which makes any of the emotional beats fall flat on their face, since they lack any kind of grounding.I wanted to care about the Mitchel's or even the world they occupied, but I don't care about cardboard cutouts.What didn't help as well, was the constant onslaught of bad jokes and tired comedy tropes with additional support by name droppings like: facebook, instagram and youtube.This is the kind of "Ralph Breaks the Internet - Emojy Movie - sh**" that leaves a bad taste in my mouth. But I could definitely imagine watching this again "under the influence".It's not boring, it's just dumb.

I loved every single moment of this movie. It perfectly reflects today's world how children and parents ditch because of different opinion, because of generation gap. Somehow,phone gets the advantage of taking the place of parents. Children now a cannot live without phones and wifi. They forgot to enjoy the nature and also forgot to spend time with parents.While watching this, I almost cried a bit. Realising I'm kind of Katie in my family, who is ditch from family and spend most of the time using phones.
Obnoxious is the best way I can describe this movie. Everything is just so over the top and annoying.

This movie's frenetic style takes a little getting used to. It lays in weird effects ranging from real-life video to cartoonish scribbles over its more conventional computer animation, which is both fun and sometimes jarring, and at first I was concerned that this was all just a way to make up for a lack of substance. But once the movie moves from angsty-teen family comedy to insane apocalypse it just keeps getting wilder and funnier, and the various visual quirks become increasingly charming.The story is engaging although unpersuasive even by the standards of kids cartoons; you could write a long list of nonsensical technology tropes (water? Seriously?) but this isn't the sort of movie where you wind up doing that; it's so fun you forgive it pretty much everything, including its sentimental and overlong final scenes.Very funny family drama suitable even for childless adults who like whacky cartoons. Well worth watching.

reviews.review_title: Predictable , corny , notfunny and overused jokes
reviews.content: Why is this getting positive reviews it's not even good.

Wow
Until I watched this animation, the best animation of the year was "Encanto" for me. But now that's definitely it.The animation technique was like in "Spider-man - Into the Spider verse".It was a very creative job.The script was very simple, but the jokes, voice acting and music were very good.I wouldn't say no if the sequel of this animation was shot.

reviews.review_title: exciting, but all over the place
reviews.content: Honestly it was a bit of a meh movie for me. I will give them credit for actually picking one genre and sticking with it (unlike the first trailer led me to believe) but it was still nothing too special. It was very exciting the entire time with plenty of action sequences and the animation and voice acting was great, but it was just so all over the place with a blantant uninterest for keeping its focus. The memeyness was pretty excessive and something i could do without, (not even to mention its going to make this movie incredibly dated in no time) and the script had a LOT of conventinces. I dunno, maybe its just because i was expecting a better plot from the creators of the lego movie and spider man: into the spider verse but the clunky script really hurt the film. But at least it wasnt the anti-technology propaganda movie i was expecting and actually ended with an overall positive attitude towards technology, that is a genuine positive for the movie.

reviews.review_title: When Your Entire World Exists Between Your Two Thumbs...
reviews.content: .You might enjoy this under-achieving snore fest. It's BRIGHT and FLASHY and has no comedic value other than the dog. Everything about this movie has been done before, and done better.

Enjoyable film, but the score and visuals make the movie from above average to great.Strong 7.5 a few of the movies messages felt a bit forced, pacing was almost jarring at times but a very good movie overall.

My first impression with this was to say, clearly, the thing that A Goofy Movie was missing (or even the human-character parts of Toy Story 3) was the AI super-charged Robopocalypse. But it's much more artistically ambitious and driven by a theatrical, hyperkinetic vision than that. Thrilling, heartfelt, hilarious. Lord and Miller productions match and in some cases surpass Pixar. It's got deliriously and constantly inspired animation, an aesthetic that works for and earns respect within 6 minutes of when it starts (what else to say about a teenage filmmaker who makes the kind of magic that is akin to Wonder Shozen, only better because it's 2021 and we've all learned so much how to do it better), and Olivia Colman voices an evil app.Without question this will inspire a ton of young people to go to film school, and hey maybe one of you will call your lovable doofus of a dad and see how he's doing. Mitchells vs the Machines is about how to or how not to function in a family, especially how a daughter with a mental/emotional block with a dad (and it's very much a Why Are Dads saga), and why having a simple conversation can, you know, do a lot. Oh, and Furbys will kill you all.And more than comparing to Goofy Movie, you know what this is? It's The Simpsons back when it was *great* - cutting edge satire, self conscious and knowing so deeply about culture right now, but with a heart as big as a... Rhombus!What else should the Black Void of Distant Space have but Wifi?

reviews.review_title: Hyper Animatied Film That Needs to Calm Itself Down
reviews.content: IN BRIEF: Family animated film that follows its formulaic root in storytelling, despite some clever animation touches.JIM'S REVIEW: (RECOMMENDED) Whenever one discusses the merits of animation nowadays, the same issue with the genre raises its ugly head: It is a rarity when both the narrative and the visuals mesh seamlessly. Usually, the state-of-the-art animation excels the storytelling. Which brings us to The Mitchells vs the Machines, the latest effort from Sony Pictures Animation, a studio that is primarily known for its Oscar-winning film, Spiderman: Into the Spider-verse. In this case, the same results follow that winning formula.This family-oriented fare is a flashy road movie with a dysfunctional family trying to save the world from a robot apocalypse. Written and directed by Michael Rianda and Jeff Rowe, the movie is a clever spin on the generation gap with a sci-fi edginess. Despite all the mayhem happening around the family, the Mitchells become the unlikely hope for mankind as they rage against the machines and try to avoid their own destruction. This mission forces the always quarreling father and daughter to begin to bond as they fight off the bots, with an overabundance of underwhelming pop tunes blaring on its soundtrack.The screenplay tries to focus on the relationships within the family dynamics, but the characters lack depth. The story settles into a series of endless chases and dilemmas. (If you want to see superb animated sci-fi about a family of misfits, may I suggest Pixar's The Incredibles series franchise?) However, the visuals in The Mitchells vs the Machines are consistently eye-catching and well rendered, although some of the animation becomes too manic for my taste. The backdrops are filled with superb detailing and the movie makes good use of its CGI.There are funny sight gags to enjoy and having all of its characters become stylized exaggerations with big eyes and distorted facial expressions, more in line with the Looney Toons cartoons of yore has its charms. (Especially fun are the comic antics of two defective robots named Deborahbot 5000 and Eric.) But the moviemakers never trusts their own instincts and never allow the moviegoers any downtime to enjoy some quieter moments. The quick edits and garish color palette, along with the jarring camera movement, seem desperate to impress wheneverpossible. Every single moment must be choreographed to be loud, bold, and brash.Fine voiceover work is done by Mr. Rianda and other better known celebrities such as Danny McBride, Maya Rudolph, Abbi Jacobson as the Millers and Olivia Colman, plus Fred Armisen, and Beck Bennett as the malfunctioning droids.The movie's main flaws are its breakneck pacing that becomes overdone and a script that needs to calm itself down. As the movie races to its uplifting climax, it switches gears and goes into sensory overload. The jumbled screenplay relies more on tongue-in-cheek cyber in-jokes and sophomoric humor that mostly falls flat as it tries to salvage the plot. The filmmakers make a misstep in breaking through the fourth wall too often in their storytelling techniques with abrupt stops in the action which jarringly interrupt the many well-done chase sequences.I suppose that The Mitchells vs the Machines would qualify for standard animation fare these days, perhaps a cut above the usual offerings. This Is ambitious and innovative animation to the max, well worth viewing. One cannot deny the talent of Mr. Rianda and company. Still, despite all the lavish creative artistry, this hyperactive film follows a predictable formula for success. It may visually satisfy some moviegoers with many innovative touches, but the movie does little for the intellect or emotions. Perhaps the robots do end up winning in the animation war after all. (GRADE: B-)

reviews.review_title: Still not sure why I indulged myself the first hour of this movie
reviews.content: This movie is bad, and I don't even know where to start.The CGI is fantastic, but the art direction is all over the place.. It feels like they tried to recreate the mix that "spiderman into the spiderverse" did, but it is badly executed, mixing 3D, comic style drawings, meme style drawings, camera/first person view, etc etc.The humour is bad. Really bad, full of cliché, stereotypes and frankly feels like they forced themselves to be funny. Idem with the "emotions" .The story is so bad it made me wonder if the script was made by teenagers. Since the movie was on Netflix, I skipped almost half of the scenes, either boring or cringey.Ultimately I also don't understand how the hell this movie has a 8 on imdb, and I question how legitimate are the other reviews.

The dialog, the scenes, it's all very cringey. And somehow in this story about an imperfect family learning to understand each other through living through the apocalypse together, nobody once utters the phrase, "I'm sorry," for all the toxic things done at the beginning of the movie and the eighteen years of the girl's life prior to the "happy ending."

reviews.review_title: I loved how the movie comes full circle and I hope they make a sequel. Very good job, Netflix.
reviews.content: The Mitchell's vs the Machines (2021) is a movie my daughter and I just watched off Netflix. The storyline focuses on a family whose oldest daughter is about to leave for college. As she is about to leave she gets into a large argument with her dad and he decides to make it up to her by canceling her flight and having a family road trip to to drop her off at college. While on the road trip, the world is invaded by robots and everyone but them is captured. Can they save the world? This movie is directed by Jeff Rowe and Michael Rianda in their directorial debuts and included the voices of Danny McBride (Vice Principles), John Legend (Coming to America), Chrissy Teigen (Hotel Transylvania 3), Eric André (The Lion King) and Blake Griffin (New Jersey Nets currently). The storyline for this was awesome and as my fiancée described it best, "like a Griswold movie." The family interactions and dynamic were so good. The the writing and the animation were awesome and the special effects were unique. The soundtrack was also very good. I loved how the movie comes full circle and I hope they make a sequel. Very good job, Netflix. I'd score this a 9.5/10.

reviews.review_title: Streaming Wars Get Out of Hand
reviews.content: How serendipitous given its big-tech filmmaking scenario that "The Mitchells vs the Machines" would be sold off from Sony, now largely an old media conglomerate, to the progenitor of streaming services, Netflix. Nominally, the tech CEO here shares his forename with Mark Zuckerberg, struts on stage in front of employees and sycophants to present new products, Siri-esque (or "2001: A Space Odyssey" (1968) HAL) PAL in hand, like he's the late Steve Jobs, a logo reminiscent of the Amazon arrow or smile thing surrounding him, as like just about every tech company stealing and abusing customers' personal data, including for robotics or some form of what's commonly termed "artificial intelligence." If that's all there was here, though, it'd be a hypocritical slap in the face to audiences--embodying the very qualities that it supposedly critiques in its Terminator-for-kids apocalypse (being especially derivative of "Terminator Genisys" (2015)). It still is largely, which along with its diabetic-levels of sugary family sap is why I have mixed feelings for it, but there's also the reflexive device of the filmmaker being a character.This, at least, allows for a less duplicitous self-serving message as distributed by Netflix. Note that the resolution to the robot apocalypse doesn't reside with the Luddite position of the father, but with a compromise of technology serving human interests--specifically, to aid in our making and viewing motion pictures. Look at how the filmmaker daughter drives the car through PAL's Silicon Valley headquarters--like a data signal being sent along cables. Indeed, like a virus as the dog's face attacks each computerized robot. Moreover, it's a film-within-the-film as presented by YouTube product placement, through the actual internet dynamics and streamed to screens big and small, that's humanity's best hope.It's obvious this isn't a serious (or seriously funny) examination of the role of technology, let alone the corporate capitalism of big tech, by the fact that the animation is entirely imbued with the aesthetics of social media and web videos. It's the usual 3D computer animation, but as if put through those camera filters, made into memes, and with the action constantly paused so as to be digested through the content creator's wisecracks for those with miniscule attention spans. Personally, I suppose I'm relatively a bit of a Luddite myself and so find revolting this sort of imagery, forms of communication and glorification of glowing faces drowning in their phone addictions, but I admire the thorough symmetry of it here, as opposed to an inconsistent bit such as, say, the texting sequence in "Crazy Rich Asians" (2018). Plus, the eye of the computer frame (or the equivalent of the no-longer-existent camera) really, manically moves. More than two-and-a-half decades after "Toy Story" (1995), it's hard to make 3D computer animation still appear a stunning spectacle, so kudos to "The Mitchells vs the Machines" for succeeding as much as it does in that respect. It especially helps that the picture is made to appear as if being constructed within by the filmmaker character--the movie proper being but an elaborate variation on "Good Cop Dog Cop."

reviews.review_title: The stylistic excesses are what make the film
reviews.content: The storyline is in the ballpark for an animated film. It is basically a more comedic and kid friendly The Matrix, I, Robot or any number of tech uprisings. The father-daughter story is sweet and they got the right voice actors to bring it to life. The script is funny and the story does what you expect but in an engaging way.But the animation is gloriously expressive. This the best representation of meme/online culture I have seen in film. Most of the animation is representative-photoreal-3d CGI done with care and skill. But over that is a layer of seemingly hand drawn (by a gifted but young artist) crayon and crude photoshop. The final film feels like it was made by Katie Mitchell.

reviews.review_title: Another visually unique animated film from Sony Pictures Animation
reviews.content: After Sony Pictures Animation released the visually stunning, Oscar-winning Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse (2018), I awaited their next project with great interest. Eventually, they put out a trailer for a movie titled Connected, which seemed to be exactly what I was looking for. Then the pandemic hit. Netflix grabbed the rights, renamed the film, and released The Mitchells vs. The Machines (2021). Ultimately, it was a fun movie, even if it followed many tropes of the family road trip.Visually, I'm finding the new style of 3-D animated movies that look closer to the traditional 2-D animated films to be an intriguing middle ground. There are benefits from both styles, and this movie takes advantage of them. Ultimately, though, I think this kind of movie knows its demographic is millennials and does its best to pander to some of our absurd humor (like a fantastic scene with Furbies) as we find ourselves coming into our life as parents faster than we want to admit. Sure, there's still some humor that appeals to the younger generations (it is an animated film, after all), but it kind of hit that sweet spot for the millennial in me.I definitely found the frenetic action of this film on par with The LEGO Movie (2014)-which itself had a unique visual style and humor that parallels this movie. All this being said, The Mitchells vs. The Machines felt unfocused. It tries to cram two full plots into a single movie, which made it feel a little bloated (at almost 2-hours long) and some of the emotional moments tacked on for the sake of completeness. For my money, I'd much rather watch Lady Bird (2017) for the "daughter leaving home to pursue her dreams in college" plot-especially since jobs in the film industry are quite lucrative.Another visually unique animated film from Sony Pictures Animation, I give The Mitchells vs. The Machines 4.0 stars out of 5.

This movie was very disappointingly stereotypical. The family is exactly like the family in all the movies. Teen that is kind of different from the rest of society, Crazy and goofy Dad, A creature loving young boy and a Jealous mom. The good side was the comedy, i really enjoyed the comedy especially the two robots where enjoyable. But the stereotypes kept it down. It was like boomers and Karen's teamed up to make this. It was very anti tech but somebody got to tell these guys they are not fixing society with their cringe movies. If it were not for modern tech you could not have ate a bunch of money from this movie.What a disappointing movie for the hype.

Decent watch, probably won't watch again, but can recommend.Expecting this to be a Dreamworks picture, I was surprised to see Sony heading this one up.Watching this robo-apocalypse story, it feels like just a weird amalgamation of other movies that happen to be cg animated, involve robots, dysfunctional families, and corporate hostilities.While all these are great elements, their combination, with the movie's special flare just falls short for me.While my disbelief is fully suspended, it just broke off after a bit with some of the goofy stuff the humans end up doing contrasted with some of the amazing things the robots are doing that actually makes some sense.The movie looks great, and is technically great, but the characters and story just fall just short for me.

reviews.review_title: Here comes Sony's Version of Pixar Classic to deliver their Best Animated film after Spider Verse.
reviews.content:
The Mitchells Vs The Machines (2021) :
Brief Review -Here comes Sony's Version of Pixar Classic to deliver their Best Animated film after Spider Verse. The Mitchell Vs The Machines is Sony's attempt to use the Pixar Formula and gratefully the outcome does match that expected level. Sony hasn't delivered so many classic films except for the Spider Verse in 2018 which is moreover a Marvel's film for the viewers so the standalone credit was still missing and with this Film they have found that Standalone Classic. A quirky, dysfunctional family's road trip is upended when they find themselves in the middle of the robot apocalypse and suddenly become humanity's unlikeliest last hope. This concept is very unique and is on the same lines of Pixar Classics. I've always wondered how Pixar manages to blend fictional characters and imaginative theories with the human emotions and that's exactly what this film does here. A little child friendly topic turns highly functional with the use of technovanza and then ends on a high note with heart-touching sentiments. Those monologues on family values brings tears and some of non-sense scenes suddenly starts making so much sense and shockingly it's doesn't even feel bad as far as we're enjoying it. The animation work is fine and the production design is innovative as they use different themes to provide some offbeat offerings. There are some problems with the screenplay because it looks little longer than expected and could have trimmed that slow beginning. Nevertheless, it recovers the shortcomings with lots of entertaining elements in the second half. Overall, The Mitchell Vs The Machines is unique, entertaining, emotional and heart touching family film that should be watched by the entire family together. A Classic Tear-jerker!RATING - 8/10*By - #samthebestest.

Great animation holy ballz I love the colors and smooth story! Danny McBride is perfect in anything voice or not he's a lot of fun has been for the last 15 years in my opinion. Abbi Jacobson does a great job with her character throughout, connects well with her father and the adventure is so good. Fairly hectic I understand any hate but the movie is awesome!

reviews.review_title: An over the top KIDS cartoon.
reviews.content: I don't know what is is about this highly rated animated film critics and audiences alike enjoyed, but I didn't enjoy 'The Mitchells vs The Machines' all that much.Initially loving the unique, fun and quirky characters of the dysfunctional Mitchells family, the excitement would wear off very soon. What started off with likable characters I somehow could relate to, the film became overdone, unbelievable and silly once the 'invasion' started. It became nothing more than an over the top kids cartoon. The film is also an advertising vessel for YouTube and Instagram.I so enjoyed the film's first act. When the Mitchells were the only people left uncaptured by the machines and they became the unlikely heroes, I completely lost interest. It just wasn't believable. Yes, I understand, this is a animated film (cartoon!!) and not to be taken seriously and for entertainment purpose only, but this is so for kids, and not a mature audience. Sure, there are some funny and enjoyable moments, but the silliness by far outweighs the fun.The antagonist, PAL - the phone - is just absurd. I mean, it was hardly a force to be reckoned with and reminiscent of daytime cartoon villains. The machines self-destructing because they couldn't tell the difference between a dog, a pig and a loaf of bread was also just silly. The film played like a spoof of post-apocalyptic films like 'War of the Worlds', 'Dawn of the Dead', '2001: A Space Odyssey', and 'Gremlins' and 'Ghostbusters', and... and... and... In short, I became bored.'The Mitchells vs The Machines' did had a few family related touching moments, and sends out a message about family bonding and family values. Fair enough, I appreciated that aspect. It was also trying to be philosophical, and begging the audience not to sit staring at their phones all day.Unfortunately, as big a hit as the film was, as vibrant as energetic as it is, this is not for my palate. If you're into animated films, I suppose I would recommend it for at least one viewing. (Munchie was by far my favorite character, and was responsible for most of the film's truly funny moments!).Would I watch it again? No.
This is a well-made movie with some good writing. It's pretty funny and does a good job investing you in the story and characters. And the animation is great. (1 viewing, 6/11/2022)

A loud, frenetic, and, if I'm being honest, pretty exhausting man vs. Technology animated film.The funniest thing about the movie is the family dog, an adorable pug that sent me immediately to YouTube to look up cute pug videos. Otherwise, the film becomes a hot mess the longer it goes on, and by the end it's a complete assault on the senses.This is one of the nominees for Best Animated Feature at the 2021 Academy Awards in a not-very-strong category.Grade: B.

The original title of the film is Super Conectados (Connected) would be released last year in the cinema and was postponed to 2021, in late January Netflix bought the rights to the film and became an "original" (I only heard about it) and changed the name to A Família Mitchell e a Revolta das Máquinas (The Mitchells vs. The Machines) I did not understand the reason to change the title and this title doesn't make sense; and the name Super Conectados (Connected) was the creative title of the film, putting memes in the film was disrespectful, the only positive point in the script is the family and technological revolution is becoming more and more advanced and due to this there were some moments completely clueless!

reviews.review_title: How are so many people giving this a 10?
reviews.content:
The animation is the only saving grace of this movie. The story is cliche and half decent at best, the humor is absolutely terrible, so many cringe moments, the writing is mediocre. There's so many plot holes and plot contrivance, yes it's a cartoon but that doesn't mean you throw all logic out the window; 1.the robots malfunction when the see dogs that means they should have all malfunctioned due to the outstanding amount of dogs in existence, you want to tell me the mitchells are the only people who own a dog in this universe
2. A device that can be used to bypass the cages is literally put inside the cages and the one thing that can open just happens to be thing the Mitchells have been carrying. How the hell did the mother even know about the device, nobody tells her and yet she is able to free herself
3.the mother suddenly gains super strength and beats the bad robots. WTF!!So many other things don't make sense. The rating was very misleading and I went into this expecting a great movie. If it wasn't for the animation I'd give this a 1. It might be fun for kids but I definitely wouldn't recommend it to adults.
7/10 - kind of in the animation style of Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, this colorful and fun flick is one of the better new animated features I have seen in the last few years.
It's just no interesting enough. I don't like main characters, they are trying so hard to be interesting, but failed.I don't know, something is seriously off, I don't enjoy watching this movie.
Worst community college drop-out could make a better movie. It is really pathetic and rating can be explained only by bots and fake reviews.

reviews.review_title: You have already seen this movie like 8 times
reviews.content: This movie was very disappointing and stereotypical. I have seen like 10 movies like this. The Story was stale and repetitive at the same a bunch unnecessary references where thrown in and it was terrible. The same dad, the same teen and the same kid and mom. Unnecessary.

One of the funniest movies I've ever watched in a while with some genuinely emotional scenes. It took pages from spiderverse and added a unique and childlike twist onto them. The memes may have been dated but it added to the charm. The characters in this movie were also very memorable and awesome (especially the robot brothers). Best animated contender?

reviews.review_title: Very Juvenile, Very ADHD, Very good design, Very good for...
reviews.content: ...Kids. Some say this is a family movie, no. UP is a family movie. This is the movie kids are finishing to the end while parents fell asleep on a couch. The most notable part of this movie is that the whole designs of the movie such as character designs and graphic designs, are very well done. Those flash cartoon contents are also very nice, however, it has become annoying later. I could also see a lot of plugs of Japanese culture especially with one of those Japanese sci-fi animation hero - I can't remember the name - which mom is portraying at the end. I guess Sony took advantage of the opportunity. Sneaky I'll say.

reviews.review_title: The adventures are wonderful, the perfect strips, super fun and exciting...
reviews.content: It seemed boring, a family facing machines, the title sums it up and it doesn't help, but what a captivating family, it seems our family, maladjusted, crazy, but that everyone loves each other, special participation of that perfect, margarine commercial in the urge, but none surpasses ours, the adventures are wonderful, the perfect strips, super fun and exciting...

This has to be one of the funniest animated films I've ever seen. The jokes come hard and fast with this new colorfully animated film from Sony. They've really taken their films to another level recently with Lord and Miller's involvement and the beautiful animation they use in movies like this and Into the Spider-Verse. The story is straightforward, but that doesn't mean it isn't a wonderful adventure full on non-stop clever humor and astute commentary. I would highly recommend this film to both children and adults.

I loved how its full of fun!I loved how it presents the family weirdness and the dad and daughter relationship.How it shows the reality in a funny and a lovely way that makes you emotional!And its a very creative movie with many creative drawings, I don't mind watching it again only to concentrate on the drawings, amazing!

reviews.review_title: It's not good but it got a few laughs
reviews.content:
Pros: Like I said it got a few laughs, and it had a few admirable moments
Cons: The character arch's were predictable, the concept was boring, you knew the family was going to survive in the end, and the animation isn't great.But like I said, it got a few laughs.

Big fan of this. Not bad for netflix movie. Plot wise not very original - something we saw plenty of times but the animation style hands down the best. Great sound effects and characters design. Amazing voice casts. Recommended.

They just gave this fun and happy twist to what is actually happening in our world and the robot uprising isnt far too. Liked the pacing and family drama, which we are all a part of, so that bond makes it a better movie, I guess. Good visuals though. I liked the idea to have actual photos at end. Good to see, better original animation movies are being made. Extra star for being fun.

reviews.review_title: Refreshing, Original, and Better than Most Disney Stuff Nowadays
reviews.content: The Good: The Mitchells vs. The Machines is easily one of the funniest animated comedies I've seen in a while. It's funny for kids, for adults and everyone in between, using a mix of slapstick, visual humour, sardonic wit, and observational comedy to great affect. This feels like a movie written by people who LOVE movies (which isn't particularly subtle, but it's fine), and i loved how it poked fun at so many tropes fro apocalypse films and waded into some minor social commentary about our relationship to tech. I can't tell you how many times I laughed out loud and a lot of it comes from minor jokes or little visual gags in the background. Good stuff.But what I really love here is how well developed the characters are. Rick Mitchell, the patriarch of the family, is a bit of a technophobe, but his reasons make sense. The protagonist, Katie, is a young woman who wants independence and to carve her own path. She's very relatable and understandable too. Despite this film's energetic and zany visuals, it's surprisingly touching and human, with relatable people, relationships, and conflicts.Speaking of which, this movie is very clever and goes in directions I didn't expect. The care put into the plot and the pacing are reminiscent of a blockbuster rather than a straight to Netflix animated film. Olivia Coleman does a fantastic job as the villain. In fact, most of the cast is really, really exceptional here.However, we all know the reason this movie has become the fan favourite it is has to do with its AMAZING visuals. I'm happy that Sony Pictures seems to have really leaned into the Into the Spiderverse style of seamlessly integrating 2D and 3D animation, but in a completely different context. One thing I haven't heard people talk too much about is how the environments are so detailed and vivid. This feels like a lived in world with a lot of attention and care put into the background.I'm not usually a fan of meme humour and internet jump cutting in film, but...The Mitchells vs. The Machines may have won me over. When done well, it really feels like a product of the current age; tailored to audiences who are used to the hyperactivity of internet content. There's also a lot this movie *gets* about the internet and smartphones that a lot of other films don't. I love when movies about the internet are made by people who actually understand it.Yes, it's a bit rough at the beginning, but it grew on me and I liked how consistent the approach was during the movie.If I would describe this film visually, it's 2000s YouTube + Scott Pilgrim + Spiderverse. If none of these things appeal to you, steer clear. If they do, you won't be able to look away.The Bad: The movie does get a bit too cute at times, with running jokes that overstay their welcome. I get it, call backs are funny, but too many ruins the stew, you know? The film is also a tad too long; we don't need to be reminded why Katie loves her family or what she's learned. We get it. Consequentially, this film has the "Return of the King problem", where it just doesn't end at the right moment. It drags on, a lot of the steam runs out and I found myself just wanting it to wrap up. Which is bad for a movie I pretty quickly fell in love with.Also, like many zany animated movies of today, the beginning is a bit weak. It takes a while to really settle into the tone this movie is going for, but i really don't know if they could have done anything to avoid that.I also found some of human characters' animations somewhat distracting. I don't know if this film has motion capture or not, it certainly looked like it, and while for the MOST PART the animation is fluid and wonderful to look at, there are awkward moments here and there.The Ugly: The Mitchells vs. The Machines is essential viewing for Millennials. I swear. This movie truly feels like a generation of animators coming into their own, truly confident about a unique style that will be remembered for years to come. This is a special movie and I sincerely hopes it wins Best Animated at the 2022 Oscars, if for no other reason but exposure.

After everyone at work recommended this movie, I decided to watch it with my family. Ohhh boy was I embarrassed. The jokes were so horrible. My brother cringed so much that he left the room after 50 minutes of watching, even though he usually loves animated movies. My father left after the first 10 minutes, but he's not big on animation anyway. My mother and sister watched it all the way to the end, but they didn't laugh once. I have no idea what this movie is trying to communicate except for 'being crazy is a good thing'? It's super on the nose. 2 stars because I did enjoy some of the robots' personalities. Sadly their designs were very unoriginal.

One of my favourite movies so far this year. I watched it with my little brother and it is rare that we watch a movie that both grabs his attention and mine but this one did.Comedy is fantastic even as an adult you will find this movie hilarious. Every joke lands there wasn't any cringe jokes everything worked to perfection.Animation was beautiful not much more to say, it was perfect. I've never seen this type of animation before which made it unique and mesmerizing.The family theme was executed to perfection. They really captured some of the problems and tension that reside in family's and showed how it affects the family in a way that was extremely well done.The pacing of plot was great and really kept your attention.A couple of plot points were iffy but it's not a huge deal. Also the story was a little generic but again not a huge deal.The Mitchell's vs the Machines is a great movie all around. Although there are a fair amount of plot holes it doesn't take away from the magic of the animation and the relatability of the family.9/10.
THIS THIS THIS!!! Peak comedic timing, incredible cast, magnificent visuals and soundtrack! Also... GET THAT LGBT+ REP!This is a great movie worth rewatching!
A must see!! Pretty fun ride. Animation is stunning! Loved it!!
It's a cute film. I found the funniest moments involved the dog or furbys.

Greetings again from the darkness. What would happen if human survival depended on the Griswolds (from the VACATION movies) battling the rogue robots programmed to take over the planet? Filmmakers Michael Rianda and Jeff Rowe answer to that scenario is hyper-active, frenetic, overly-busy visual chaos that attempts to blend apocalyptic science fiction, extreme action sequences, and dysfunctional family comedy-drama. It's a lot to tackle, and for the most part, it works.Katie Mitchell (voiced by Abbi Jacobson) is preparing to head to film school. Her nature-loving dad, Rick (Danny McBride) is concerned about how he and Katie have drifted apart over the years, and he's also worried that her educational choice could lead to disappointment. Katie's mom, Linda (Maya Rudolph) is mostly supportive and upbeat, and yet a bit saddened that the once close father-daughter duo no longer speak the same language. Youngest son Aaron (voiced by co-director Rianda) and family dog Monchi have their moments, and mostly this is a fairly typical dysfunctional family. In fact, dysfunctional family seems to be a misnomer since it describes most families, even the highly organized one that seemingly have their act together ... represented here by the Poseys (Chrissy Teigen and John Legend).Katie's generation's adoption and dependency on technology has widened the gap in connection with the previous generation ... specifically the bond between father and daughter that was so strong when she was young, and now barely hangs on by thread. Dad is the generation of the supreme screwdriver, while Katie is all about creating memes and videos. He fixes things, while she creates things. Dad decides a family road trip to drop Katie at college is the solution to fixing the frayed relationship. This happens on the same day that mega-Tech guru Mark Bowman (Eric Andre) is introducing his next-gen PAL robot, which is smart technology on steroids. However, it turns out, software has feelings too, and the original PAL (Olivia Colman) seeks revenge for being replaced. An army of robots is sent to capture the entire human race.A couple of quirky things leave the Mitchell family as our final hope against the robots, and as you might expect, saving the world can lead to reparations in the father-daughter relationship. Dad gains an appreciation for the creative skills of Katie, while she learns of his great personal sacrifice for family. It's an unusual blend of two distinct stories, but mostly we are left exhausted after a nearly two hour run time. The screen is often cluttered and overloaded with distractions (including old school Furbys with a twist), and although there is a cool throwback look to some of the animation, it's simply too much of a good thing. Younger kids may be mesmerized by the frantic action, but the story lines are not likely to be followed by most under 10 or so. This one has garnered a great deal of Oscar buzz, which makes sense as adults decide such things.Streaming on Netflix.

reviews.review_title: Sony hits another homerun in the animation film market
reviews.content: I was planning on watching this movie last year but I, unfortunately, had a lot of things and other movies that I prioritised over it. Thankfully I have finally been able to watch it this year and I am absolutely glad I did.Phenomenal and stylistic animation with eye-popping visuals. Quirky and unique characters. A meaningful and heart-warming message with wonderful characters arcs. A great music score with good utilization of songs. Excellent writing with quips and jokes that actually made me laugh.The Mitchells vs the Machines is an amazing animation film that is great for the whole family. We all heard of Pixar, Disney Animation and Dreamworks but Sony Picture Entertainment is showing that they are just as, or even more so, capable in the animation film market.

reviews.review_title: Stupidly Fun and Made with Love
reviews.content: There are some movies which make you laugh a lot, cry and in the end be grateful.. The Mitchells vs the Machines is like that. Yes, the first 30 minutes is a bit slow and very cliche, there are so many, I mean so many plotholes(if you want to call them that) and you know where this is going. Please don't be that person. Don't go on and say, "Well on second this doesn't make sense at all" or say, "I guessed this thing happening from the start, so predictable". Just don't. This movie's plot is stupid but it is stupidly fun and has a heart. Almost all of the jokes land, both for the kids and the adults and I mean that's a very hard thing to accomplish. Yes there are some jokes which were already very popular but come on as I said, don't be that person. The plot starts very cliche, and it continues to be cliche but somehow it makes it feel original and real even though the characters are very goofy. The movie goes to the limits with the goofiness and that's why this is the most fun I had while watching a movie recently. The soundtrack is also very good, both the songs picked and the themes(which had an electronic vibe, I loved that) are so good. THE COLORS... I mean this movie is also visually stunning, I mean the cinematography. I didn't expect it to be well-thought like this. Both the nature and the electronic(neon lights stuff) look astonishing, my favorite part of the movie. I highly recommend watching this with a family member(the more the better) as this is that type of movie. The type of kids movie which not only makes the adults enjoy it as well but also makes them enjoy it together. For example in Pixar both kids and adults enjoy the film but for the different reasons but in this film they will enjoy the film together for the same reason: "The Experience". This "experience" is a double edged sword though because this movie isn't memorable but the memory of you enjoying it with your family will be.

reviews.review_title: A cliched emotional rollercoaster with gorgeous animation
reviews.content: Okay so at this point we all know that if we see, "From the people who brought us Spider-Verse and Lego Movie" that most likely this animated movie is going to have an amazing story and outstanding animation because this movie continues to prove that. When I first watched the trailer for this movie I thought that this story was just going to be a cliched movie but overall there are some elements to this story that are cliche but this story no matter what will hit you hard. This is a story that everybody can easily relate to whether it be a wacky family like this or just a crazy friend group. This story is for everybody, especially those who find it hard to fit in. This fact goes for the characters as well I found myself multiple times saying I related to multiple characters as all of these characters are fleshed out to the point it's impossible not to see yourself in one or more of these characters. Now, onto the animation part of this movie and oh my god is this animation gorgeous. The colour tones of this animation with the little switches between the regular animation of the movie to a more rougher-looking animation is just what makes this movie unique and stand out amongst the others. I also love the difference in the tones from when the family is just driving around compared to that of the robot city. The last thing I'll touch on is the music for this movie and how great the soundtrack for this movie is. I for sure will be listening to it while I study for school and do schoolwork. In the end, The Mitchells vs the Machines may seem like a cliche story but it's one with gorgeous animation and lots of emotion in it.

reviews.review_title: The Incredibles meets iRobot, only cringy
reviews.content: I was expecting a good movie, given the amount of positive reviews. After seeing it I can't believe they are real. This whole movie is the family version of I'm NoT lIkE oThEr GiRlS. The girl is so weird because she likes movies. The brother is so weird because he's interested in dinosaurs. The mother is weird because she believes in everyone. And the dad is so weird because he likes outdoor stuff. The whole premise is that this family is special because it's not like other families, while everything that is supposed to make them weird or special is as normie as it gets.It attempts to do current day references, but instead of merely referencing, they have to spell it out for you. "My dad reminds me of that screaming monkey clip. Let me also show you the clip in the actual movie, and even crop his head on my dad." Very funny humor. All the memes were outdated before they started making the movie.The animation is very good, and the comic infusions are fresh, but sometimes they are too intrusive and take you out of the action or the moment instead of enhancing it. However the sound design does not match the visuals. Especially the music is weak.The movie has two messages, first that we became so dependent on technology and robots that they took over the world and decided to get rid of the inferior humans. Second, that generations have something to learn from each other. The problem with the first message is that there is no solution. At one point the person responsable for the end of the world says it might not have been such a good idea to give away all the data to unregulated companies after all. And the dad agrees, but it allowed his daughter to upload youtube videos, so it wasn't all bad. There is no solution, nothing is changed at the end. The problem with the second message is that the out of touch father closer resembles todays grandparents, not parents of teenagers. And the bonding doesn't feel natural. The final product is something that falls short. It should have kept it's message to either technology or the family, not both.

Overall, The Mitchell's vs The Machines was a very solid and entertaining animation. The creators behind Spiderman Into the Spider-Verse were involved in this film and you can clearly tell by the brilliant animation. It's just beautiful to watch and it shows the level of talent in the animation game right now. The story itself was fine, albeit slightly cliche, with a lot of hilarious humour added throughout. The animation and the comedy really make this film what it is. There wasn't any obvious negatives that I noticed, I know it's aimed at younger viewers, but the animation was the main reason behind watching it and I'm glad I did. A superbly well done, meaningful film with a lot of heart put into it. 100% recommend if you fancy a casual watch - Go treat yourself!Quote - 'You guys are my people' - Katie.

reviews.review_title: Watched this movie late at night and still didn't enjoy it
reviews.content: The animation was wonderfully done. Most of the good comedic moments came from the animated popups that would appear on screen a la Zombieland/Spiderverse; hats off to the animation team.The rest of the movie was so derivative that it was on the point of parody, which would have been great had that been intentional. It attempts to be some kind of combo between Zombieland, The Lego Movie, and i,Robot but doesn't commit to what made those movies successful within their respective subgenres. So many other films have already done this but executed it much better. It was an example of the current state of many movies being made by bigger studios in the animation industry: the filmmakers knew how they wanted to begin the film and end the film and padded out the rest of the time with lazy, boisterous worldbuilding (think Soul, Inside Out, Frozen 2).

Katie is a weird girl on her father's eyes, they keep arguing al the time till mr Mitchell decided to take the family on a road trip trying to get his daughter close to him again, at the same time a tech company called pal released new robots to make human's life easier before they became a threat to the humanity.Well animated and colorful mess, it was super fun and funny, I laughed so loud while I was watching.A very worthy Oscar nomination for this beautiful project.What an excellent chaos!I really admired Olivia Colman's voice."Shouldn't you two be dead!".

So, this is it... This is the final formula for animations from now on... Netflix young adult product engineering... Animation used to be a progressive art form to push boundaries and achieve something original. This is worse than anything... What a waste of effort...

It's nice, but as an adult, this didn't quite stick the landing for me. The weaving of various animation styles, the trope-y scenarios, the miscast voice acting for a particular character. I just felt the overall plot was a little generic, though I did enjoy the emphasis towards the connection between the characters, which I guess at its core is what the film was really about. It's fun, and there are some laughs to be had, but it's definitely catered towards younger audiences.

reviews.review_title: MY FAVORITE MOVIE OF ALL TIME!!!
reviews.content: The Mitchells VS The Machines is one of those film I have been waiting forever, the character designs, Katie's design is AWESOME, The animation is also awesome, amazing story with the robots and the filming which relates so much of myself10/10 is what I'm giving, one of my favorite movies of all time, MUST WATCH.
Don't know why its over rated could be CGI, but animation without a solid plot is a waste of time.

reviews.review_title: I usually don't give short reviews
reviews.content: It's a meh. The animation is good but it's just fast-paced mediocre garbage. I'm 13 and my sister is 8 so we're kinda in the target demographic and both of us thought its deserving of a 5/10 since both of us have watched worse films.It's like a kid friendly version of I, Robot just worse with one dimensional characters. Id say the rule of thumb is if you or your kid is under 10 they'd enjoy it. One of the things that pained me through the movie is It's full of clichés, stereotypes and boring jokes.Now that I think about it if this is the type of stuff that's getting fed to us now it's only going to get worse from her :/

reviews.review_title: One of the best animated films I've seen!
reviews.content: This film is fantastic! Memorable characters, good humour throughout and a story about family that is quite touching and beautiful. What to say about the animation? It's SPECTACULAR! A mix between 2D and 3D along the lines of the great "Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse". KEEP IT UP SONY ANIMATION!

reviews.review_title: Anything can happen because most of the major plot elements are determined by blind luck.
