reviews.content: The great thing about plots based on luck is that the writer can make anything happen whenever she wants it.In this film, a statue luckily falls on 2 robots who are luckily not destroyed but, instead, have their programing luckily broken so that they can help the heroes.The robot overlord luckily discovers exactly where the heroes are going but its thousands of flying robots luckily can't find them.The heroes have a dog whose appearance luckily disrupts the robots ability to operate. Knowing this, the robot overlord luckily doesn't change its robots programming to stop that.Cages holding the captured humans luckily have the unlock mechanism right inside the cages.The super-phone containing the robot overlord is luckily not water-resistant.Movies based on this (known as deus ex machina) are pointless since any difficultly can be instantly resolved without any action by the film's characters.

*) K reviews *) ( ( What an entertaining way to tell you that indulge in each other and remove these screen boundaries and blue light faces. Anyway, the movie is a 2hr of non-stop entertainment and that's a guarantee. Don't miss it even if your PAL is about to destroy the whole humanity.

The Animation in this Film is Extra Ordinary. You'd think Sony Animation Studios exhausted their talent in into the spider verse, but no, they still got something up their sleeve.You see this film and rewatch Raya and the last dragon, and its like Raya was released 5 years ago.Sony just have to seriously work on their story department and develop original plots like Pixar. If they do, Disney is No Match.
I was so in love with every single element in this film. It is the movie I knew I needed in my life right now.A+

This is probably in my top five animations ever in my 12 years on earth.It was hilariously funny, exciting, and deeply emotional at times. And the animations were VERY high quality.All of this combined makes The Mitchells vs the Machines an amazing movie that I definitely recommend you watch.

Well, let's start from rating... This movie is so overrated, how it can have about 8 Imdb, that's a mistery for me. It's good animation movie but only for kids. I don't see how it can interact with adults. It just performs that very badly. It's very messy to watch, a lot happening in one scene, then 20minutes of no action, then again action in one scene and silence after that. The main idea is kind of good but not original, there are plenty of movies with the same idea and I'm looking for something unique. Can't give it more than 6 and I wouldn't ecourage people to watch it. Better pick Raya and the Last Dragon, Frozen, Shrek or any other classic movie.
Its one of the best Cartoons in recent times .... Sony Animations is kicking Ass ... Disney should take Tham as an good example for how it's done the right way.

This film is just a boring way of presenting 'The Incredibles' served on another plate.The animation is beautiful but the writing and/or the editing is bad. Some scenes are too quick to enjoy and everything is missed because of that. The writing is more like any other film of family bonding and family problems. The conflicts the Mitchells face are easily resolved. There's nothing that makes a connect except the cliche & simple scenes between family members.

reviews.review_title: Feels like a PG rated version of Family Guy
reviews.content: A happy but incredible goofy family go on a road trip, but become in the middle of a robot invasion, and the question is, will they make it out alive and stop it , before it's too late.Most of the jokes feel like a PG rated version of Family Guy. The animation is well done, so was the voice acting. It was trying to be for kids and adults. Not a masterpiece, but an amusing film to pass the time and to forget about your problems.

A film I saw because of the Oscar post-hype where much of the critics were talking about how, yet another year, Best Animated Feature was not fair.Is it a children's cartoon? Yes. But there's more, its reading of family relationships in adolescence and early adulthood is at a higher level than most pixar films (except inside out), as well as dealing with feelings from a real point of view as something that doesn't change from one day to the next and self-acceptance as part of the road to maturity. The treatment of LGBT people is one of the best of recent times, they don't need to wallow in their orientation for the creation of the character, it's just something that is there and treated as something normal not something that comprises and forms your whole SELF.As for the more technical aspects the film doesn't excel at anything but it doesn't lose out to its competitors, it's a film that doesn't get long, it doesn't lose pace at any point and the songs/moments of music are perfectly implemented.Oscar stolen.

reviews.review_title: An Eccentric Suburban Family Deals with Inner Turmoil and Existential Crisis
reviews.content: The tried-and-true tale of a family road trip, one father's last misguided attempt to mend rifts and connect with his teenage daughter before the latter departs for film school, is rudely interrupted by a robot apocalypse. This particular mechanical coup d'etat comes at the behest of a thinly veiled Siri knock-off, an artificial intelligence that's finally tired of our mundane requests and verbal abuse. As the literal last family standing, the dysfunctional Mitchells must work through their private issues whilst also steering the station wagon around misbehaving smart appliances and, somehow, rescuing the entire human race.Beyond the silly robo-invasion and hilariously unlikely action scenes, it's effectively sharp and sweet, eccentric and real; one of those rare films that speaks to parents and kids on their own level while still maintaining a shared common ground. It's also a wonderful visual showpiece, furthering many of the concepts that first came to light with 2018's Into the Spider-Verse. I really dig that trend (dare I call it a house style?) from Sony Pictures Animation, a fresh mixed-media experiment which meshes smooth, stylish 3D models with effective spurts of kinetic, hand-drawn line art. Those play into the plot, baking personality into the frequent asides that fill out the family's back story, while also lending a quaint, made-with-care aura that illuminates the whole screen; they're downright charming.Well done on the graphical front, then, with only slightly lower marks on the narrative side. The Mitchells are an entertaining, colorful bunch, with an admirable amount of time dedicated to developing the secondary cast. Pacing isn't all it could be, though, given the deflating early anti-climax and a third act that drags on for too long. Maybe a few too many wink-nods at internet culture, too, but that's only a minor quibble. Overall, it's good. Really good. Good enough make me to wonder if Pixar might have finally met a worthy adversary.

reviews.review_title: Sony Pictures Animation made something original and good?
reviews.content: I remember seeing trailers for this when it was called Connected, and I dismissed it as another subpar movie from Sony Pictures Animation. Then the pandemic hit and Netflix picked up distribution rights, and the reviews started dropping, with astoundingly high praise. I had to check it out.Katie Mitchell (Abbi Jacobson) is a college-bound filmmaker whose father Rick (Danny McBride) is the last person to understand the world through her eyes. In a last-minute attempt to reconnect, Rick cancels her flight from Michigan to California, and proposes that the family take a road trip to drop Katie off. Along for the ride are doting mom Linda (Maya Rudolph), dinosaur obsessed younger brother Aaron (Mike Rianda) and family pug Monchi (Doug the Pug).Meanwhile, in Silicon Valley, tech giant Mark Bowman (Eric André) has released a monumental update in his PAL virtual assistance program (a cross between Apple and Google), but has disposed of his own device (Olivia Colman), which goes rogue and unleashes a robot uprising.Right from the opening logos, one knows they're in for a treat. While it does hit some familiar beats, The Mitchells vs the Machines is filled to the brim with a fully utilized ensemble voice cast, film references, self-awareness, laugh out loud humor, heartwarming moments and even one of the best (and subtle because y'know those uppity conservatives out there) acknowledgements in an animated film of an LGBT relationship.If this is the kind of original content SPA is going to dole out, please keep on. We so desperately need it.

reviews.review_title: Sony, King of the Animation Studios
reviews.content: The most visually dazzling animated film I've seen since "Spider-Verse" and the best one Netflix has distributed since "Klaus," "The Mitchells vs. The Machines" stakes its claim as a modern "Incredibles." Brimful of detail-oriented frames and elaborate settings, it feels like a graphic novel come to life. Succumbs to that sometimes frustratingly manic pace, but with such effectively handled pathos, you might not care.

reviews.review_title: Do yourselves a favor and have a good time with this one.
reviews.content: In a world of reality tv and ridiculously vile cartoons, it was good to see a film like this that had a family aspect to it. And I have to admit that The Mitchells vs. The Machines was a refreshing change. Sure there are a lot of jaded reviews on this film, but see it for yourselves before you take ANYONE'S opinions as facts. All of the voice overs were done excellently and the comedy was better than most live action films that I've seen recently. Do yourself a favor and have a good time with this one..
So funny. A great family film. Kids age 10 and 6 loved it - as did we. Really hope there are more like this.

reviews.review_title: Script is not just improv, it's bad improv.
reviews.content: I definitely see the attempt to force some of the market-tested Gravity Falls elements in here but none of them work. The boomer humor won nothing but grimaces and second hand embarrassment from my family, and I felt really bad about recommending it based off reviews. I hated the outdated gimmicks, script and dialogue so much it completely overpowered the excellent textures and animation. It kind of reminds me of the humor of that dreamworks film Home tbh. The equivalent of thumbing ones nose at the audience for two hours.

I'm genuinely surprised on how even some critics think this movie is good in general. Even as a kids movie it's really bad.The few good things I can say about it is it's high budget animation and its creative stylistic designs. However, the other "qualities" I have to say are far from similar.First of all, the sound design and mixing is really awful. I can't tell why newer movies such as the recent Tom and Jerry seem to face this problem also.The movie wants to take itself seriously and also wants to make the viewer laugh at the same time and it fails at it miserably. For an odd reason this movie reminds me a lot of the movie "Home". With its same annoying characters and flashy designs. It also is similar to home in the fact that they both wanted to do the exact same thing, the only difference is that this movie did it slightly better in some aspects and is way more praised for it.It was clear from the beginning that this movie was going to "Capitalize on the modern generation" of people. Don't want to spoil, but I'm sure even the people who won't admit it know how hard this movie is trying to relate with certain groups of people directly.And finally, I dislike how the whole plot in general starts and ends. But I'm sure you'd already have figured that out.

reviews.review_title: Visually stellar, but fails on every other level.
reviews.content: I awaited MATM with eager anticipation; I know several people who worked on it and it's easily the best looking animated feature since "Into The Spiderverse".Alas, the film turned out to be a mind-numbing experience full of inane post-modern humor and frivolous, noisy action which completely failed to engage or satisfy me on an emotional level. What's worse is that it just wasn't funny, at all. Out of the mile a minute gags that are fired about memes, phones, cat filters, surveillance capitalism, killer kitchen utensils and pugs, about 98% failed to even register a smile. Mostly it just comes of as annoying. They had the opportunity to do some punchy satire here, but it's all very low brow and childish. The lackluster voice acting didn't help either.Structurally, it's a mess. Many of the scenarios feel like they were selected with a dartboard at a writers session (a throwaway sequence involving an army of Furbies at a shopping mall being one such example).There are no real threats or stakes and so we have no reason to care about anything that happens, or believe the heroes might fail. Stuff is just thrown at the screen in a haphazard way and explained with some lazy dialog exposition.When we're supposed to care about the feeble father/daughter drama at the core of the film, we just get some soft piano chords and a few sad eye closeups. Compare the storytelling of Mitchells to say The Incredibles, which has similar themes, and it really feels lacking.I was so bored after 40 minutes, I almost gave up. If I have to give any credit to the film, it goes to the artists who have done an exceptional job creating a unique and striking visual style. What a shame to waste that talent with such a mediocre story.

reviews.review_title: One of the best animated films in years
reviews.content: Wonderful film packed to the brim with colourful, fun and energetic animation. The animation is quite similar to Sony's previous film Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse with the hybrid hand drawn and CG animation which is very pleasing to the eye. It's amazing that this is the same studio that created The Emoji Movie, especially given how funny and clever this one is in comparison. The voice cast is great as well with Olivia Colman delightful as the evil AI trying to remove humanity from Earth.My only real problem is that some of the references in the film will probably end up quite dated in a few years time so it won't have that timeless feel that many of the great films have. However, it's still one of the best animated films I've seen in years.

What a good fun time with the Mitchel family as they fight the robot insurrection while drying their daughter to film school. They go thru all the regular family conflicts but with such wits and little fun tricks you can't decide which one u like more.

Here's The 4K Lowedown on "The Mitchells vs. The Machines" (PG - 2021 - Blu)Genre: Animated/Invasion
My Score: 8.6Cast=10 Acting=8 Plot=10 Ending=10 Story=7
Art=8 Voice=7 Music=8 Intense=9 Invasion=9A quirky, dysfunctional family's road trip is upended when they find themselves in the middle of the robot apocalypse and suddenly become humanity's unlikeliest last hope."I'm here to bust criminals and lick my own butt. And I'm all out of criminals." I really liked this...very much like Zombieland with its narration and comedy. It has an amazing cast, but it was hard to recognize the voices...which I liked about this movie. This just recently came out on physical media, but it has been on Netflix for a while. This is a great watch!

This was a vibrant and fun ride! The whole family has such perfect chemistry and the watercolor animation was beautiful to look at. I also liked seeing how playful the editing was, almost like I could tell the creators were having so much fun making this. The Mitchells vs The Machines is incredibly entertaining!

reviews.review_title: Couldn't make it past the first 25 minutes
reviews.content: First of all, the celebrity voice casting trend is something that should be put out to pasture. Sometimes it works, but a lot of times, like in this movie, it falls apart completely. Danny McBride is a very funny guy, but he's totally miscast and I doubt if he can pull off the nuances of voice acting. Similarly, Maya Rudolph doesn't bring much to her role, either.But the dialogue and personal interactions aren't relatable at all, so they lose any potential to be truly funny or engaging.Also takes a long time to get going, with a lot of pointless scenes. Hard pass on this movie.

reviews.review_title: PERFECT Comedy Feel-Good Animated movie for all ages!!
reviews.content: Finally. A comedy animated movie for people of ALL AGE to enjoy. The right amount of good humour, logic, morals, and also execution! Can't express how much I loved watching this animated movie.I legit sat down with my sister to watch this film, with no expectations (since we didn't see any reviews or even the trailer). Got up at the end cherishing every bit of it. DEFINITELY WORTH THE WATCH!

reviews.review_title: A movie that tries too hard and fails
reviews.content: I kind of liked the beginning, but it went quickly downhill. The characters are bland and the dialog forced. There are so many cringe moments in general and very few of the jokes are actually fun. I hated the artstyle of adding "filters" to the characters in the movie but I respect that some might like it. Tye story about the american core family is just not interesting. Also, why the f did they cast the little kid with a grown mans voice...?
I liked this movie. It had heart along with all the technical stuff I like characters. The drawing were a little jarring at first, but you get use to it soon.

I had to pause and go do something else about 3 times before I could finish the whole thing because everything was either too cringey or frustrating. The dad was incompetent and bullheaded who absolutely could not handle his own precious baby daughter having! Her own personality! And interests! And the teenager was so stereotypically teenager that it's like whoever wrote these characters was an alien who never interacted with an actual human before and learned about humans by watching other movies with cringey dialogue and one dimensional characterization. And they definitely have beef with technology and social media. I've never felt such strong desire to stop watching an animation before. Who was the intended target audience for this? Children? Gen Z? Gen Z will laugh at this and spit in its face. They've seen better content on tiktok. Not even gonna talk about how the Mitchells were the only ones in the entire world who didn't get captured. (jk I am). Because really. Out of 7.8 billion humans? Really? It's shown that these robots aren't capable of detecting humans who are hiding behind objects so...how'd they get everyone underground?I'm honestly confused by the high ratings... Some reviewers were even saying that this was as good as Into the Spiderverse. No way. Forget about being on the same level, the two aren't even in the same building, or even the same country, for that matter. Nothing about this was creative or unique.Wanted to give this a 1 star but the animation is honestly amazing, the 2 robots were actually funny (but were the only funny things in the movie), and I'm glad to finally see a good sibling bond portrayed in media. But that's it. Would not even show this to my own children.

I saw this movie because I read that it was very good, at the level of SpiderVerse and man, very difficult to see, the jokes are bad, the script is bad, all the time it feels very forced and is too long, almost 2 hours for a animated film, it was a total waste of time and I do not understand what the rest saw that they liked. Yes, the animation is great.

reviews.review_title: Full of Heart - Left me with Teardrops
reviews.content: This movie was an absolute delight and I was definitely pleasantly surprised when I watched it. A fun family movie full of heart and connection, sometimes without too many words. It was all in the feelings which was carried beautifully. Also, had some subtext if you're willing to pay enough attention.The animation was brilliant, bright and exciting. The characters were sweet and relatable but sometimes just annoying, which makes them even more relatable because that's kind of how people are. A thoroughly pleasing and enjoyable experience and with a whole lot of re-watch value. Plus, the music was perfect.This movie surely made me question how underrated Sony movies are because I think they do a lot of good work - especially by taking risks. This movie was off an original script with no franchise backing but was pulled-off beautifully.
Best family movie I've seen in years! Funny and entertaining.

The animation was refreshing and it had its cute moments but this felt really forced.I was thrown off with how formulaic it was which made it feel very flat and predictable. All the typical bits, lines and gags condensed into a movie made it feel almost jarring. Even the dumb quirky pet shtick is getting pretty old.You can tell it wants to be a smart, witty, movie but when it's beaten over your head you can't help but recoil and question if it really is interesting as it presents itself.

This just isn't my type of movie unfortunately. I don't like the animation style, the humour just doesn't click with me and the story is just paint by numbers.However I know that's just how I feel, it's a perfectly fine movie. Nothing makes it unique for me apart from the inclusion of an LGBT+ character in a kids movie. This is a huge step forward and people who criticise it have no idea how much it means to see people like you on screen for kids growing up. It makes me happy that kids have that.Does that make it a good movie? No but I'm so happy that it happened.

reviews.review_title: The Mitchells vs. The Machines might not have the catchiest title, but it's definitely one of the best animated feature films of the last years.
reviews.content: If you enjoy reading my Spoiler-Free reviews, please follow my blog :)When it comes to deciding if a certain film is added to my watchlist or not, I consider various factors. From genre and synopsis to cast, directors, and screenwriters, sometimes just a familiar name can convince me to give that movie a go. Producers and/or executives are far from being remotely influential in this type of decision. However, Phil Lord and Christopher Miller have directed/written/produced some of my favorite animated films of the last decade (The LEGO Movies, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse), so obviously, I needed to watch The Mitchells vs. The Machines, previously known as Connected. Mike Rianda has his debut as a director, screenwriter, and voice actor (Aaron Mitchell, son), accompanied by Jeff Rowe, the other writer.2021 is shaping up to be a phenomenal year. It truly is. I absolutely loved Soul and Wolfwalkers, but if this Sony Pictures Animation flick came out last year, I genuinely don't know which one would I put higher on my Top10. Rianda and Rowe deliver a brilliantly original screenplay, packed with incredibly relatable characters and beautifully handled themes. I can't quite remember the last time I laughed out loud when watching an animated feature by myself. Every joke about technology is hilariously clever, making fun of ridiculous yet realistic human behaviors regarding malfunctions, low speed, and even lack of Wi-Fi. I cried of laughter, but I was also close to dropping a couple of tears due to the main narrative.I'll start with the protagonist, Katie Mitchell. As a young, aspiring filmmaker, Abbi Jacobson's character follows a well-known arc about not having friends, being the so-called weirdo, and having parents - in this case, more her father - who simply don't understand who she is, what she likes, or why she loves something they simply don't understand. While it's true that this storyline isn't exactly new, it doesn't mean it's not captivating and emotionally powerful when written and developed properly. Rianda and Rowe make Katie an extremely relatable character in such a seamless manner that it's harder to not connect with her than the contrary.Anyone has at least once in their lifetime felt left out or alone. Obviously, since I share the exact same passion as Katie, it's easier for me to feel precisely the same as her once she discovers new friends with whom she can talk about the art she loves the most. I still have no circle of friends who I can meet daily to discuss the latest movie news or newly released films (in-person), so Katie's journey does have a more significant impact on me than it might have on other viewers. However, it doesn't have to be about art or a specific subject. In a general analysis, Katie just feels lonely and wants to follow her dreams, but feels unsupported by her father, Rick Mitchell (Danny McBride).One of the most compelling aspects of The Mitchells vs. The Machines is the fact that Rick and Katie share the same arc, just going in different directions. While Katie feels like getting out of the house and going away forever is the best solution to all her problems, Rick believes that her staying with the family is the safest route, one that features no failures that could hurt her emotionally - something that Rick learned from his past, hence the necessity of overprotecting her daughter at all costs. Since they're on opposite sides of the spectrum, constant fights, lies, and hurtful comments drive them apart, leading to a wonderfully written story about family, love, friendship, and understanding the other side of the argument.Katie's mother, Linda Mitchell (Maya Rudolph), and brother, Aaron Mitchell (Rianda), serve more as triggers to heartfelt conversations with the two main characters, but they also have their own personal journey. While Linda feels jealous of her Instagram-perfect neighbors and embarrassed of showing off her own family photos, Aaron deals with his bizarre love for dinosaurs in a lighter, funnier way than Katie's dramatic arc. Both storylines carry their own lovely messages to transmit to the audience, but Katie and Rick's confrontational relationship embodies sensitive issues that tons of families across the globe never find a solution for.Another remarkable characteristic of this screenplay is how Rianda and Rowe never take a definite stance on any topic. They always try to follow one of the movie's main messages and present good points for both sides of the conflict. For example, The Mitchells vs. The Machines could easily be misinterpreted as an attack on the Internet and technology in general, but every dialogue is exceptionally balanced. While comments are made about using our phone at the dinner table or during family moments, as well as excessive screentime and overreliance on social media, new technology can give birth to the most inspirational, motivational, and influential works of art. Without it, Katie's dreams would be totally different.Transitioning to the more technical elements of the film, it's impossible not to tackle the new animation style. Into the Spider-Verse was an experimental movie, and its success might have changed the future of animation forever. The mix of a more illustrative, hand-painted approach with another focused on the CGI realism seen in most films today offers - just like the movie itself - a seamless balance between the two supposedly opposing styles. This blend allows keeping the expressiveness and extreme level of detail of the classic method while also maintaining the realistic environment of the 3D/CGI design. The action sequences are extraordinarily energetic, riveting, and quite impressive, to say the least.The film's soundtrack (score by Mark Mothersbaugh) is on-point, elevating dozens of scenes with excellent music choices that most viewers didn't even remember already. Exquisite editing (Greg Levitan) and outstanding voice work across the board. I genuinely can't find a single issue with this movie, and I'd be extremely surprised - and disappointed - if it doesn't end up being a frontrunner for next year's awards season. Both kids and adults will have tremendous fun with this fast-paced, highly entertaining film while also getting a few valuable life lessons along the way. And who knows? Maybe this movie will inspire families to make that road trip they've been planning for ages...The Mitchells vs. The Machines might not have the catchiest title, but it's definitely one of the best animated feature films of the last years. With a beautiful blend of two animation styles - that may impact the future of this type of movie - Mike Rianda and Jeff Rowe deliver an emotionally resonant story about family, love, and more explicitly, placing ourselves in someone else's shoes. Featuring incredibly relatable characters, the remarkably written screenplay strikes a perfect balance in every topic it approaches by presenting arguments for both sides without ever defining something as right or wrong. The character arcs might be well-known storylines, but the exceptional writing elevates every personal journey, especially Katie and Rick's, daughter and father. Boasting great voice work from everyone involved, the fast-paced narrative still holds impressive, colorful, screen-popping action sequences filled with energy, excitement, and fantastic song choices. It's one of those uncommon films where I can't find a single flaw with it. A must-watch, *hilarious* film for both kids and adults.Rating: A.

I wasn't really that impressed. The story was fine, but wasn't super into it. Been there, done that. Characters were ok, didn't really like the disigns, but overall pretty human and likable. Humor felt kinda forced, some jokes were genuine, but most were just kinda forced. Overall good movie, but super or anything.6/10: cool and good.

While the movie was full of cliches and twists and turns you could see coming, I found myself smiling and pleasantly surprised by the end. The visuals and animation were well done. A great family movie and worth a watch.

reviews.review_title: Dull, full of plot holes, and unimaginative
reviews.content: This movie is trying so hard to convince the audience that it is original, clever, and fun that it fails even more miserably than it would just on account of its tested "dysfunctional family on a road trip formula". The story is so predictable that I was able to guess not just what happens next, but also the lines of characters basically through the whole movie. It's packed with old pop culture references and bad, overused jokes. The fact that the main characters seem like a bunch of stereotypes on steroids instead of loveable people, and that their relatedness is basically constantly rubbed in the audience's faces doesn't really help. Not to mention that the plot is not really driven by characters' actions, but instead relies on constant "deux ex machina" magic, which only gets worse as the movie progresses. The animation seems desperate to be quirky and fun with all of its technique mixing, reminding us at all times that the main character is a child, no, a product of a YouTube and smartphone filter era, experiencing the world through a smartphone lens, a stark contrast to her well-meaning, nature loving father, who is portrayed not only as a complete ignorant when it comes to technology, but also as a totally socially incompetent idiot that doesn't understand that a pink screwdriver is not an adequate wedding anniversary gift. But, hey, every member of our cardboard box family luckily had one, because that was exactly the thing needed to save the world in the end. This movie was so disappointing, boring and annoying, and all those fantastic (Paid, obviously!) reviews were so infuriating that I created an account just to post this review.

It's great that other studios have started making animations and it's not only Disney and Pixar. The Mitchells vs Machines is one of the good animations I've seen funny, happy, relatable, the cast does a good job but Danny MacBride stands out as the best. The only thing that bothered me is the fact that the plot is cliche and so predictable. Overall it's a fun movie to watch.

It's senseless but emotional..
it's illogical but funny..
it's woke but not preachy..

Oh dear. This movie has a cool story line and admirable lessons about over-use of smart-phones and the dangers of AI. Kudos for that. But the execution is dreadful.The most jarring thing for us--and this includes our teenagers, presumably the main age-category this movie is aimed at--is the habit of the movie to every two minutes or so drag the viewer out of the story with some super-clever, supposedly zany moments where the graphic style completely changes, or an actual YouTube video is shown, or rainbows or other irrelevant artifacts parade across the screen, and so on. It means that one's nose is every two minutes rubbed in the fact that this is an animated movie and not real and not serious.Call us old-fashioned, but for the time we watch a move we like to believe in the universe it portrays. To be pulled out of the movie all the time is just jarring and we ended up with a shoulder-shrug: why watch this zero-second attention span rubbish?And... is this the new thing? Just before watching this, we tried The Willoughbys, and switched it off after 20 minutes, for this very reason. The most recent The Croods movie was hampered by this weirdness, though not quite as frequently. Have the days of the inherently consistent animated story telling of Ratatouille, The Lion King, How To Train Your Dragon, Studio Gibli, etc, really gone?Secondly, the movie was far, far, far too long. If it had stopped after the showdown in the shopping mall, we'd have given it 6 out of 10. But after that it continued for half an hour with mawkish, toe-curling, utter cringe, sentimental rubbish. Of course, it moves slowly and inexorably towards the final big shoot-out, which every American movie needs to have, it seems, and omg, is this section cringe and so unrealistic that all credibility and creative tension goes out of the window. The mother gets angry and turns into a robot-destroying, flying, super-hero. Super-cringe. The father and daughter also suddenly have super-powers and surf through the air and kill tons of robots. Cringe. And so on and on.Of course, physically impossible things happen in most animated movies all the time. But, again, a movie needs to be credible within its own parameters. This movie just doesn't care, anything goes as long as it's deemed funny, whether it's weird colours, weird flags, the YouTube videos, feats that were impossible two seconds earlier, characters turning into superheroes just because they get angry, and so on and on. Despite the on-point messages, sometimes rammed home too explicitly, both our teenagers judged the movie a cringe mess, and we could only agree.

reviews.review_title: Another worst animation film! Full of boring conversation, and annoying overuse scene! Avoid at all cost!
reviews.content: This film start with the narrator talking about the machine apocalypse, and the introduction of family Mitchell scene! As turnout, this film is about family Mitchell need to defeat a bunch of robots control by the so called "PAL" chip, and eventually sending Katie safe to her college! Entire film full of boring conversation, and annoying overuse scene! Such as, overuse of the dancing scene, overuse of the singing scene, overuse of the song playing at the background scene, overuse of the eating scene, overuse of the arguing scene, overuse of the driving scene, overuse of the slow motion scene, overuse of the playing dumb scene, overuse of the watching video scene, overuse of the staring scene, overuse of the texting scene, and overuse of the video recording scene! Make the film unwatchable! Barely intense scene is, Linda grabbing the core of the robot to kill it! At the end, after the mastermind fell into a cup of water, and the machine apocalypse been prevented! Katie safely arrive at her college! Family of Mitchell driving the car to receive medal at the very end! That's it! Another disappointed film!

This is one of the most unoriginal movies I've seen in a while. Young girl wishing to run away of her family and go to college? Lady Bird made it better. Bad relationship with the dad? A pendrive to save the world? Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs made it better. Group of people driving through the country during a apocalypse? Zombieland made it better. There is nothing new to see here. Olivia Colman is the only good thing about this film, her lines are good, she is charming as always. Like her character said in the movie: That was soooo boring.

reviews.review_title: Great animation and sharp satire, but ultimately a bit underwhelming
reviews.content: I really wanted to like this more than I did. In some ways, this was admirably witty, meaningful and satirical, poking daggers at modern society's dependency on technology. This played like a kid-friendly version of Black Mirror. On a purely technical level, this was awesome, filled with beautiful, vibrant, sometimes surreal, animation. But why do we keep giving passes to family movies where everything works out too perfectly, action scenes end too neatly, and things become so predictable by the end? I mean, maybe I've watched too much Japanese animation, but the best anime clearly shows that you can make kid-friendly movies and series, and still be intelligent, unpredictable and unafraid to slow the pace down. But movies like this and the How To Train Your Dragon series are so frenetic and tidy. It's like the scripts have no breathing room at all, or any sense of real danger.This is still very much worth seeing though. As I said, the animation is stunning. The humor is also strong, and I found myself actually laughing at a lot of the jokes, which isn't normally the case even with other highly-touted cartoons. The satire on technology was spot-on, and there were a ton of amusing references to past science fiction classics (ie. The main villain, a smartphone, was named PAL, and most young audience members wouldn't even know 2001: A Space Odyssey).As is par for the course when it comes to childrens' movies, you also have some good lessons about family. However, making the Mitchells quirky outcasts isn't as original as the writers seem to think. So many family movies recently have quirky, "different" main characters. Ever since The Incredibles and maybe even earlier, it's been a thing. But for young audiences and families, the themes and messages here are admirable and effective.The action sequences were very well-presented and kinetic, but I started to get tired of the typical "the baddies are winning, no the heroes are winning, no the baddies are winning, oh the heroes won at the last minute" structure, where luck and coincidences began to stack up like the floating boxes that the humans were trapped in. And there's no need to make things so simplistic for the kids. As I said, plenty of cartoons, especially from other countries such as Japan, are much more natural in how they handle action sequences and overcoming adversity. Here, the ups and downs of the battles felt too forced, and the victory of the Mitchells at the climax felt too inevitable.So, definitely things about this I appreciated, and for a family movie it's very solid. But more discerning viewers may not be as satisfied.

God this movie is a blast. Tremendous animation, great voice work, it's hilarious, the family elements really work and just... Aaah. It's incredible. Go watch it, it's on Netflix and it's great. Just watch out for flashing lights.

reviews.review_title: Fun watch, but watch with a kid.
reviews.content: I'm very weirdened out by the overwhelming positive ratings on different platforms this movie has! But then I thought about it and realized, maybe this movie isn't for me. The thing is, I don't know who is it for. If I was to rate it the same way I rate Disney or Pixar or Dreamworks movies, I'd give it a 1. But maybe this movie is made for children and only for children, in this case it's a solid movie. But if it was trying to be of higher caliber like its peers, then I'm afraid it doesn't do it for me. And since it's rated 18+ then I guess it's not for children...The plot is painfully predictable, the story is generic, the qualities of the protagonist is recycled from every and each movie you've seen in the past decade, the 'modern' touch has always been cringy to me but I'm not judging the movie for this as I understand it's a personal preference. And the 'funny scenes' aren't really funny. The only redeeming quality this animated feature has is the great animation! The style is very lovely and refreshing, even if generic, but has a personal touch on it. Other than that, it's nothing special, and if I wasn't working while watching it I would have probably paused and watched it some another day then forget about it.

reviews.review_title: lots of cool action, but kind of boring
reviews.content: Too PG, predictable, nothing innovative, one sentence story.

Machines is one of the most risk taking animated movies I have seen in a long time, and there is something here for the adults and the kids. The movie does something that I believe only great movies do... it remains wildly unpredictable while comfortable and clear at the same time.The movie has some very bold and convicting messages about our relationship with technology and its affect on us, while delicately telling an age old story of a father and daughter who have trouble seeing eye to eye.This movie has everything -
1. Danny McBride screaming hilarious lines at the top of his lungs.2. A dog whos ending character arc is him getting to wear a tuxedo.3. Beck Bennet and Fred Armisen as two malfunctioning robots.4. Evil Washing Machines5. And an action sequence centered completely around a nostalgic 90's childhood toy.And the jokes in the movie are written so well.Most movies will have the joke... do it.. and then move on.But Machines does this thing where when you feel like the joke would normally stop then they hit you with one more unexpected laugh. (Dad Crying in the corner scene, had me rolling)The daughter in this film is the lead role, and her dream is to be a film maker... so keep your eye out for some major references to movies like Temple of Doom, Star Wars, and Ghost Busters.The final portion of the second act of this movie, might be one of the greatest action sequences i've ever seen in an animated movie. You can really feel the original ghost buster's vibes in that scene.If I was baking this movie for you and I had to use three other movies as ingredients they would be:1. Shaun of the Dead
2. I Robot
3. Cloudy with a Chance of MeatballsI highly recommend this movie, and can't wait to see more from this team in the future.Check this one out with the whole family!

It's nowhere near as good as the early reviews will have you believe. Likeable characters and a decent story can't lift this beyond being a Pixar wanna be. It lacks the heart to be that good.The facetime animation overlays are also more irritating than innovative. I enjoyed it enough to see it through, but it was a bit of a slog getting there. 6.5/10.

reviews.review_title: The family isn't that dysfunctional, but what a fun experience
reviews.content: Sony has done it again and gifted us with a new top-class animated film after Into the Spiderverse. The Mitchells vs. The Machines is the directorial debut of Michael Rianda and follows the young filmmaker Katie through her family life, which is mainly characterised by the constant arguments with her conservative father. When she learns that she has been accepted to her dream film academy, she can hardly wait, but before that she has to go on an impromptu trip with her family, which is haunted by a sudden robot apocalypse.Even though there are no real actors behind animated characters, it is the voices of various actors that make their mark on the film. Danny McBride and Maya Rudolph in particular lend a lot of charm and comedy appeal to Katie's parents with their pointed and perfectly timed statements. If you've thought for a while that Olivia Colman can do anything, this film finally confirms it. Her voicing of the antagonist Pal, who is not even a real person but a smartphone, cannot be surpassed in absurdity. The choice of which characters the film focuses on is very balanced, making none more important than the other. Katie may be the protagonist, but her parents and also her little brother Aaron get just as much time and space to shine. The latter is going through a phase of obsession with dinosaurs (and honestly, who didn't have a phase like that back then?) and doesn't want to admit his growing interest in girls. In general, the characters are very relatable despite their fictionality and it never feels like you're watching an animated but a "normal" feature film. The highlights of the cast, however, don't even come from the Mitchell family. Or actually they do, because their dog Dirk is part of the family. He, in combination with two robots who undergo a change of heart after initially having bad intentions, makes for scenes in which you really laugh your head off. It is precisely these stupidly optimistic but incredibly endearing characters that give this film so many more facets and make it a real laugh-fest.Generally, there is very little to criticise about The Mitchells vs. The Machines. The characters fit, it's a feel-good story that's stripped but never over the top, and above all it has its heart in the right place. The fact that every premise says that the Mitchells are a dysfunctional family is far from reality. Yes, they have their problems and the father-daughter relationship in particular is a big focus of the film, but in the stages the characters go through, these behaviours are only common. The somewhat forced imperfection of the family makes them even more normal, which is a bit distracting in some parts of the film. In general, the plot is not the most original - robot-apocalypse, "dysfunctional" family saves the world - who doesn't know it. In the course of it, however, there is a lot of social criticism of society's internet and mobile phone use, which is an important and nice bonus. The Mitchells vs. The Machines is a feel-good adventure that will bring a lot of smiles to our faces in these difficult times.

reviews.review_title: Lord and Miller do it again
reviews.content: Although I don't think it quite matches the brilliance of Lord and Miller's other animated works (Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, and my personal favorite of theirs, The Lego Movie) The Mitchells vs. The Machines is a rather smart, wickedly funny, beautifully animated, and quite original little flick. First off i'll start out with the films flaws, which really narrow down to one thing in particular. The thing that annoys me most about the film is easily the familiar story and family situations at hand. Not only does it feel like we've seen it countless times before, but it just feels so forced, it really drags from the fun the film has to offer. Besides that, I really did enjoy the flick for what it was- a fun little animated adventure which is truly jam-packed with jokes that are certainly my kind of humor. Mochi the pug is easily my favorite part of the film, although I do feel it's unfair to say that, because anyone with a brain could see how he was gonna be the showstopper the entire time just from the film's trailer. The animation is stylish and fully realized, much like the style of Spider-Verse with some new kick to it. At its core it's a sweet film, and it will tug on the good side of your emotions from time to time (when it succeeds at what it is trying to do). In the end, there's much to say about a film like The Mitchells vs. The Machines but too much would easily spoil it. I encourage animated movie fans to check it out, as it is quite delightful. It has its problems, but it's very unique, and is bound to make you smile along the way.My Rating: 7.8/10.

It's not a masterpiece like a lot of 10/10 reviews are saying and it's not hot garbage as the other low ratings tell you.Well the story was cliché and the comedy was wacky and some might find it cringey and forced, but I didn't mind. I liked most of the comedy.It's very fast paced and loud.Nothing new here and the story is not that amazing but it's a fun movie to watch anyway.The best thing about it is the animation.
The animation is awesome just like spider man into spider verse and the movie's story is emotional and heart touching. Overall it is a brilliant movie to watch.

reviews.review_title: Cringe. Are we heading towards Idiocracy?
reviews.content: Agitated, fast paced, shallow and plain stupid. Allot of it I recognise from all sorts of other movies or from pop culture, copy/paste remix, like a Frankenstein collage. How people are enjoying this is beyond my current understanding.

What happens when ai is too smart? Take control of word of course! But you have your family with you to save the world. It's not important that they are weird because everyone can show some goods. Funny family is the best on the movie and it's beautiful graphics.

reviews.review_title: Good, but it could have been Great. Lost a bit of sight of the main messages under loud disjointed and jumbled comedy skits. But this is the right track for Sony Animation!
reviews.content: I have taken a look at other reviews in this site, most of them give them 10s across the board deeming it quirky, funny and with fantastic animation. While I don't deny these great qualities, this movie should be judged in regards to its context: the animation movie industry is going through a very unpredictable time with fantastic animation gems popping up every other year but overall, with studios not being able to maintaining a trustworthy reaction to the hype they are building.While most of them turn out to be entertaining, funny and incredibly well animated, the story is as much a part of it as the other elements, more important even so. You'd imagine this would be obvious yet most of the movies that are released lack a deep delivery of their message. It is as if, today, style is valued more than substance and this preference affects the legacy of a movie. I am one to believe, however creatively and commendable the animation and humor and references in this movie were, the story leaves much to be desired. The trailers and plot summary presented a great premise, with seemingly cliched themes but the promise of a different, refreshing take on them. Nevertheless, from minute 1 the pacing of the story is disjointed and all over the place and this approach to storytelling is maintained throughout the movie which may be the reason why the people that mention it believe that the movie is "too loud and with little to say".But don't get me wrong, the movie has some really great moments and themes that I felt gave depth and meaning to the interactions and relationships of the characters. The approach to a dysfunctional but loving family, that simply members of it sometimes do not connect as the new and older generations have to deal with the arrival of technology as a crucial part in the lives of their young ones. A recurring theme that while at first hinted at a good message to the kids to leave their phones, didn't quite stick the landing. By referencing the meme culture, the culture of having to experience everything with or on your phone felt a bit wrong because we could see ourselves reflected in those screen-obsessed people, missing all the fun and action that lies out there. And perhaps that's another disappointing aspect I saw in the movie, the trailers made us think the movie would deal with the "nature vs technology" side, extravagantly decorating the finale with a robot apocalypse, while telling the story of why the dad and the daughter drifted apart and eventually found a way to "reconnect". And in a way they did... But it did so in 2-3 scenes in the entire movie.The development of these messages was not progressive, building up in a cohesive manner. It came and went when it pleased falling behind the comedic moments and other plot elements. The movie was called "Connected" and why this was changed to Mitchells vs the Machines escapes me, perhaps it'd was a better choice for marketing purposes but still. The title lead me to believe the movie's main theme was going to be reconnecting with a loved one and other subplots related to a fun family film, which it's true we ended up having; however the movie was missing that coming of age tale to conclude the arc of the main protagonist who I can't help but confess I disliked in some parts of the movie as her lack of simpathy and selfishness was unbearable.The rest of the family felt one dimensional as their almost quirky-cliched personalities had almost little to no relevance to theirs or the overall plot. And this is especially harmful with the character of the mom, which I personally find absolutely offensive as her passive presence makes her almost useless (not to mention her "transformation" in the end which completely came out of nowhere and felt absolutely out of character). And the humor, while great many times, felt like the movie was throwing a handfull of arrows into the air hoping some would hit the target. THe abundancy and constancy of them stopping the scene and therefore the pace of the story was jarring and annoying.IN CONCLUSION, the movie felt promising and the experience was entertaining and fun. It's just that it turned out to be an average family movie and perhaps the hype that Sony Animation's Spiderverse left behind provided huge expectations about the release of this one. Expectations that, in my opinion, were met in the animation department; but were very underwhelming in the character and plot development. I related to many themes displayed in this movie: not being understood by my family (also as a creative type myself too), wanting to find people like me who appreciated my creations,... Had this movie focused more on the emotions and messages more than the world-dominating and funny skits, it could have been one of my favorite animated movies. *sigh*

It is impossible to watch this. It over uses every resources to try to be funny and it isn't. I was expecting something like Aliens vs Monsters but this is far from that. I hope movies does not become this thing in the future.

reviews.review_title: A joyous adventure for the whole family to enjoy
reviews.content: Directed by debut feature length filmmakers Michael Rianda and Jeff Rowe and overseen by the animation geniuses that are Phil Lord and Christopher Miller (of Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs, The Lego Movie and Into the Spider-Verse fame), Netflix's latest family offering The Mitchells vs the Machines is a huge win for the streaming company and Sony's animation studio with this memorable offering likely to be one of 2021's premier animated outings.Filled with a vibrancy, energy and winning mix of heart and humor that only few animated films can dare dream of conjuring up, Machines is an abundantly joyous affair that may have a familiar finding ones-self message and odd-ball family dynamics at its core that are prevalent in everything from Toy Story to The Incredibles but Rianda and Rowe ensure everything here feels fresh and new with Machine's barely pausing for a breath across its near two hour running time.Following the Mitchell's, with dorky dad Rick, loving mum Linda, dinosaur loving young boy Aaron and the films movie obsessed lead Katie taking center stage as the world finds itself battling an A. I uprising courtesy of some new smart phone technology that has gotten too smart for its own good, this a film filled to the brim with unique and colorful animation and is a feast for the senses in that regard but its also a film filled with frequent smart humor and great set-pieces, meaning viewers of all ages will find something to enjoy here throughout the entirety of the films length.Helping things out along the way is the great collection of voice actors the film managed to get together to bring the Mitchell family too life with Danny McBride, Maya Rudolph, Abbi Jacobson and co-director Michael Rianda all bringing their characters to life with enthusiastic and energy filled voice performances while Olivia Coleman, Eric Andre and scene stealer Doug the Pug likely to steal viewers hearts and memories with some great little turns in limited screen time.With so much going on and a laugh a minute mandate, Machines still manages to find time for significant moments of heart and emotion and balancing things out in a great fashion, don't be surprised if this memorable animated outing hits you right in the feels when you least expect it but at the end of the day, this is just a joyous adventure that further establishes the animation genre as one of the most constantly enjoyable operating today.Final Say -While there are many familiar parts to The Mitchell's vs the Machines, this Netflix animated adventure is a joy to behold and will have you laughing and potentially tearing up across its joyous journey.4 dog kisses out of 5.

reviews.review_title: My favourite film of the year so far!
reviews.content: The Mitchells vs. The Machines is quite an amazing surprise, and what I consider to be the best film of the year so far. A film bursting with madcap energy, creativity and imagination, I enjoyed every second of it! It has great animation and stylised character designs that are very expressive, and it has such a wonderful dynamic between the Mitchell family that is wholesome and quite relatable. Also, the two defective robots and Monchi the pug were absolutely hilarious! Definitely a 10/10.
Michael Rianda joins animation royalty (Brad Bird et al) with one of the sharpest scripts in years.
Light and very funny family movie that deals with the general theme of loving family. Full of quotes and exciting and fun moments. I consider it a small masterpiece of modern cartoons.

The movie is entertaining. I enjoyed the animation style, it was creative. Some of the jokes made me actually laugh. And it was heartwarming.. very heartwarming.. sometimes too heartwarming! And a little bit stick up for big corporations (maybe because they've funded them?) I definitely liked the family centric message and humor.

reviews.review_title: Someone gave a YouTuber a movie contract.
reviews.content: Story was okay besides some of the obvious agenda and typical relationships. The excess extra art, reaction related effects, and YouTube references made it really unbearable at times.It's a movie. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

I liked the movie. It's funny, the animation is very colorful and even brings a beautiful message about family.I'm just not giving it a 10 because I think the movie was too fast paced for my taste and I also think the animators overused the 2D effects to the point of being too boring.Anyway, it was worth the Oscar nomination and I recommend watching it.

This is just amazing. It's definitely 2021's best animated movie and one of the best movies ever. It's all enjoyable, funny, emotional and deep. The screenplay is brilliant with many awesome lines. It implies lots of great messages and sheds light on many interesting topics like family, generation gap, diversity, human nature, human enslavement to technology, teens' obsession with their cellphones, etc. All tackled in a beautiful highly entertaining very well written story. The Mitchells Vs The Machines is just a flawless touching hilarious family movie go see it now, it's on Netflix.

reviews.review_title: New Year's eve only comes once a year - for a good reason
reviews.content: At first I was impressed by this nice, chaotic family, the funny dialogues, crazy scenes and ideas. But after 15 minutes it started to annoy me. The jokes, the humour, the family dynamics - everything is brushed up to speed and amusement in such a way that it has exactly the opposite effect. I don't want to say that the film doesn't have its moments, but as a whole I find it too forced to be cool, young and hip. One has the feeling that the makers were terribly afraid if they slowed down, that nobody would be interested anymore. If every scene in a film wants to surpass the previous one, there is no tension anymore. If we had fireworks every day, no one would be looking.

An absolute blast of a film. I went in with moderate expectations but came out thoroughly impressed. This has a great visual style provided by the same people behind The Lego Movie and Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse. The animation style pops and feels unique compared to other animated films which I liked. I also love how the animation was used to incorporate comedy because the film is pretty hilarious. If you don't enjoy subtle pop culture references then you might not like the comedy but I think the set up and punchline of almost every joke worked. They even pause the film at times to make a joke which worked sometimes and other times it kinda deflated the tension but it didn't bother me that much. A lot of these story beats feel very similar which is a common complain I hear and I do kinda agree with it. There really wasn't a lot story and thematically wise that surprised me but I still like it because the writing is great. While the basic story threads are predictable, the circumstances are nice and refreshing with a take over the world kind of story. It was a fun take on a story that can be seen as predictable. I thought the emotional beats the film laid out hit a lot and some of it hit different for me as I am also going away to film school just like the main character. The characters all feel very fun and refreshing and I liked their little arcs that they went through and the voice cast did a great job as well with it. If you are a fan of animation then you will love this film. I would highly recommend checking it out.

reviews.review_title: A real treat for the whole family
reviews.content: What a pleasant surprise this movie was! We watched it as a family on a Saturday night. It was my 10-year-old son's turn to choose the movie and, honestly, when that's the case I usually get ready to zone out as I'm not expecting a film I'm actually going to enjoy. Not so with 'The Mitchells vs the Machines'! I thoroughly enjoyed this hyperactive, crazy, artistic, hilarious and endearing animated romp. It was an absolute treat!The script is very on point with regard to what's happening in the world of technology. The artwork is fantastic, with a unique mixed-media style of CGI layered with some traditional drawn styling. The voice acting is great. The comedy timing is exceptional. The story is solid, and all in all it's just a really well-put-together animated movie that the whole family can enjoy.I note that it's up for an Oscar this year. It absolutely deserves it.Highly recommended!
Great film! Funny, beautiful and sad moments. Amazing animations and really, really creative!

Emotions, A+ humor, crazy action for the kids, a well flowing plot, and true to heart topics and humor for adults. I laughed. I nearly cried. For me, it was a near perfect experience. So I gave it a 10. <3 Mitchell family has my heart!

Feels like a Gravity Falls X Terminator movie, the animations are a treat for the eyes and the voice acting is great! The characters voice actors and actresses fit the characters well. Fits modern age with the inclusion of old and new memes. While creating some. The music fits the retro but modern theme and the character development is great too. I can't express how much of a masterpiece this is. Alex Hirsh helped make this, so it's epic!!!
So chaotic and ridiculous it ends up being amazing. It handles family dysfunction way better than most other movies I've seen. It's basically Next Gen but better in every way.

Into the spider-verse was perfect animation, from beginning to end. This movie had moments of near perfect animation but they were short. Most of the time the background was like they did decades ago which I'm ok with, actually kinda like it, sort of an homage to snow white and the likes. Most of the time the part they want you to focus on looked awesome ( I should interject my personal opinion here; a lot of animated movies today look like they were made by computers, this type of movie looks like it was made by humans. I like that ) unfortunately they added these very cartoony extras, which would be alright with just a few, but they put so many of them I got tired of them. Like chocolate sprinkles !! A few is ok but ten thousand of them on a single doughnut or cupcake upsets my stomach.

So I just finished watching the Mitchell's vs the machines and if you're on the fence about watching it I suggest you do it.The whole film feels like it's on a sugar high similar to the squirrel in 'over the hedge' so for some people it could be rather intense. But with a really wholesome 'don't give up on family' theme throughout it manages to have you laughing at its silly humour and routing for the Mitchells by the end of it. This style of animation seems to be the way forward now and I'm all for it.I'm making short, snappy, honest reviews about films now because I'm bored of all the negativity that's in the reviews section on IMDb these days.

We are in the social media era where people are addicted to the internet, spending an entire 24 hours with their eyes glued to their smartphones' screens. We see the ramifications of the status quo making an ever-broadening rift in the fabric of the family. The Mitchells is a dysfunctional family but it's the turbulent relationship between Rick and Katie Mitchell, the father and daughter, that takes the centre stage here. The father doesn't even bother to pay the slightest attention to the interests and hobbies of his children. Although we witness the story from the point of view of the cinephile, teenager Katie, the movie never takes sides or even shows a smidgen of bias towards one of them. After wistfully reminiscing over the sweet memories he shared with his daughter, Rick misses the old days when they were still happy and bond together, and plans a road trip, clutching on the hope they could revive the memories of the past and rekindle his relationship with his daughter in the process. Alas, he is oblivious to the fact Katie in no longer the child she was back then, and, most importantly, to the generation gap between them. Linda Mitchell, the mother, is almost as obsessed with social media and tech devices as her kids. Maybe that's why she seems to be aware that Rick's decisions are at odds with Katie's mentality. One small, fleeting detail I loved about the movie is how it captured what the elder sibling feels whenever the younger sibling go along with the parents' choices and decisions while this younger sibling should be the first one to complain and make a fuss. It's also worth noting that, although a critique of the present tech-dependent society, The Mitchells vs. The Machines doesn't vilify the social media or technical advance. Rather, it depicts it as a double-edged sword, and that can be seen later in the movie.In the second act, the plot kicks off. A machine uprising ensues as an AI named PAL turns on her creator Mark. Yes, this is a story of an AI takeover in which robots try to wipe out the human race. Seems like a very well-worn story that's tailor-made for preaching the message this movie is going for, right? Well, yes. But, there's more to this than meets the eye. The movie doesn't content itself with what it did establish and introduce and impatiently waits for the moment the consequences of the plot ratchet up; it uses the adventure the family go on-which is built on a rather overused trope, that of "adversity forces a dysfunctional family to get to know each other and ultimately finds a common ground"-to put the flaws of every family member, mainly Katie and her dad, on full display. By doing so, the family seems to regain the compassion, affection and trust towards each other, for flaws, imperfections and inconsistencies are human, which contradict with the ostensible perfection of the world of social media. This is a theme writ large in the movie. It's actually the fountainhead from which the plot is knitted and also from which it unravels, but details that foster this theme are all throughout the movie as well. Our titular family itself is the obvious one, but in one of the strokes of comedic genius of the movie, the only two friendly robots that team-up with the family agains all the life-threatening robots and machines are actually malfunctioning. Back to the evil side, PAL's reason to exterminate the humans race seems to be an amalgamation of more or less the same factors that caused The Mitchells to be the dysfunctional family it is, which makes PAL a really compelling villain.I've been waiting this movie since it was named Connected! The two movies that instantly popped into my head after the first stills from this movie have been released are DreamWorks' Captain Underpants and The Willoughbys, a Netflix Original animated film that came out last year. In terms of its animation style, it seemed to me to be a bit similar to them, especially since the latter is also about a bunch of weird family members. After watching it, though, I noticed that it's kind of in the same vein of Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, also produced by Phil Lord and Christopher Miller, as each of them marries various types of animation into a seamless final product. I was also reminded of Gravity Falls as it feels like the movie is influenced, especially regarding its slick and simplistic animation and goofy yet warm humor, by the modern era of animated tv shows. To my surprise and delight, I found out that the movie is actually directed by Michael Rianda, one of the creative directors who worked on Gravity Falls! Nevertheless, I'm two minds about the humour in this movie. Whilst the sight gags and the internet memes and the aesthetically-pleasing hand-drawn hearts that pop up on the screen emit a touch of levity as well as a light sense of self-awareness, the majority of the jokes, which are mostly infantile, felt like a low-hanging fruit. However, the movie more than makes up for that thanks in large part to Olivia Colman's hilarious voicing of PAL.
It was perfect those of you who have kids to watch it will go crazy. It has many lessons, one of them is that without internet we can not get even a minute.

reviews.review_title: A unique style with so-so storyline
reviews.content: Great to see another kind of "animation language" that deviates from the typical Pixar style. Using real world footage and 2D imagery on top of 3D as an example works really well.The animation and art direction is absolutely fantastic. That by itself was a solid 9 of 10.I would say that the story however was a bit boring and cliche. There was also an abundance of 'American family morals' that started to annoy me around the 2nd and 3rd act.Lastly, the character abilities were over the top; turning them into super-super heroes that behaved exactly what made the screenplay move forward ruined any form of suspense for me.

If the script writers were as talented as the animators this would be one of the greatest films of all time, but they weren't. It's almost like the owner of the movie studio let his favorite niece write the script. I think it is supposed to be a comedy. It reaches vaguely amusing for a few seconds here and there. The story itself, who knows, who cares. I was just praying for it to end. Luckily I managed to persuade my 8 year old daughter to go play Jenga with her grandmother 30 minutes before the end of the film.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful animation and good voice acting that's about it
reviews.content: The humour is just so bad. The plot and characters are just so bad. I could not enjoy this no matter how hard I tried. Animation is great and so is the voice acting so why can't the actually do some good writing?

I've seen worse. Some funny parts but not an original bone in its body. Cliche AF! And the horribly miscast adult voice over for the kid utterly destroyed the movie. It stuck out like a sore thumb. Not even close. I'd say nice try but it wasn't. What was the casting director thinking? And when something so obvious like that happens, one of two things is going on. Either the shot callers are all morons or the voice actor of that part begged or called in a favor. Hey, dude, it ain't the movie's fault your phone stopped ringing. When you're done, you're done. Stop what you're doing. It's despicable and you're making a mess. Thanks for ruining it for everyone else. Great job, guy.

reviews.review_title: Why does Netflix always have to ruin good movies with woke garbage?
reviews.content: If you are a woke and support their nonsense then you will be happy with the movie, the main character has flag pinned on her jacket to make sure that this good movie is submissive to the herd mentality.

I had read that this is comparable to Spiderman into the Spider-Verse and it´s not, just like it´s not comparable to Klaus; both of which are awesome animation movies for adults. The Mitchells vs the Machines is only to be watched with children (and not even 15+). It will make you laught out loud a couple of times but the story is childish and predictable and the animation is bad.

I don't understand why this movie is getting so many 10/10 reviews. Did I watch the same movie as everyone else?The graphics are nice and stylized.... that's all I can give it.The plot and characters are meh at best and the focus here is memes. Just, so many memes. They actually break moments of tension to force in a meme. Heaven forbid you actually got 2 seconds without an outdated meme shoe-horned in, don't want you to get emotionally invested in ANYTHING going on.In The Incredibles the line was "when everyone's special, nobody is." This happens here. They aren't characters they're quirks created specifically to meme something and it gets loud, obnoxious and cringey very, very quickly.Maybe good for entertaining the five year olds but I doubt they'll recognize any of the decade old memes and fads this movie is pushing.

reviews.review_title: The movie should come with a flash warning!
reviews.content: Okay yeah, that was evident in the trailer but I didn't really imagine I shouldn't blink, and like their dog (Monchi) focus my eyes at two different points on the screen! I'll probably have to re-watch it and focus on the borders of the screen this time to make sure I'm not missing the anime, but it's not worth a re-watch.Is it funny? A bit. Is it predictable? A bit. Is it worth 2 hours? Ehhh, no. But if you're out of anime content, want to watch something with a light message or keep kids glued to the screen, it could work.Also the "little brother" Aaron, didn't sound little at all.Is The Mitchells vs The Machines an animated version of I, Robot?

Great voice cast and gorgeous animation from the same people who did "spiderman into the spider verse" and the "the lego movie".I found this being really funny and weird but fun in that way, also the characters were funny and likable.

reviews.review_title: I made an account just for this review.
reviews.content: Dialog doesn't feel natural and is just awkward at many times throughout the movie. I thought to myself "who talks like that?". The writing is frustrating because the story feels disjointed and things escalate and de-escalate very quickly. The movie trys to give you the pov of the main character, Katie, with different 2d animations sprinkled through, but it doesn't keep to her pov very well and feels weak and watered down most of the time. The art style is good but the animation fluctuates from good to clanky. I was really looking forward to this movie, but was surprised at just how frustrated and disappointed I was.

reviews.review_title: the rating of 8 may be proof people are getting dumber
reviews.content: Pretty much like the humans in the movie. Poor plot, dumb jokes, the same cliche animation style blah blah blah.
Never seen a weirder animated movie than this. Everything seems forced. I have never felt more awkward, watching an animated movie before.

reviews.review_title: A Fun Road Trip Robot Apocalypse
reviews.content: The Mitchells vs the Machines is a really fun movie for the family. Is the story perfectly told? Not really since it can sound a bit generic at first. But is this movie executed well? Yes it is. The heart does come to the right place thanks to a message about spending time with your family. Considering it's from the producers of Gravity Falls, the animation really stands out in 3D. The characters are enjoyable. The action is engaging when we get to the robot apocalypse element. And the best the movie offered that surprises me a lot, the comedy. This has contains the funniest comedy Sony Animation has produced in a long time. Seriously, I couldn't stop laughing how screw ups the Mitchells are especially Rick. This is not just a movie fun for the family, but I definitely would recommend this for those that are in a mood for a road trip movie. This is a really fun road trip I've experienced.

reviews.review_title: The humorous collision between two generations in a technological apocalypse. Believe it or not, it works.
reviews.content: We finally have a movie with a plot that reflects the interaction of a largely common family with today's technology. Here we see how the internet, social media and viral videos generation collide with the old hobbies (like camping, cooking or hanging out with the family) generation. And not only that, but we also see this collision transform into a fusion where emotions and family ties work as glue.Humor ad hoc to the context everywhere: embarrassing situations, personality conflicts, awkward movements and much more, always in total synchrony with a very well told story and a very well achieved animation, especially focused on gesticulation and precise body communication to every scene. Perhaps the only bad thing could have been an excess of enthusiasm in the approach and construction of the villain to overcome, exaggerating the adverse event to overcome.Fully recommended to watch with your family and play to identify with each character, as the film also includes as an ingredient some deep reflections on how to improve interpersonal relationships within the family nucleus, as if something were missing to complete the almost perfect production of the creators of Spider -man Into The Spider-Verse, who with this work secured their ticket to next year's great prizes.

reviews.review_title: Not super original, but I don't care
reviews.content: Lots of recycled plot elements from The LEGO Movie and Cloudy, but also tons of heart and plenty of laugh out loud moments. It's kind of awesome.
This was amazing. Great action. Awesome and creative animation. And the story was perfect for the times we live in. Fun ride!
It was hilarious. I loved it, my friends loved it. I really hope for a sequel some day.

reviews.review_title: The best animated movie of 2021 (and of all time)
reviews.content: Probably the most entertaining and best movie of 2021.

reviews.review_title: The greatest animated movie Sony has ever made!!
reviews.content: This is a great move because it is a nice movie. This has very accurate premise and most creative designing principle. Most astonishing and bright animation.

reviews.review_title: So much happening but still boring
reviews.content: The slapstick and fast edits are hard to watch. We don't see the robots for twenty minutes and the only buildup is about a young person wanting to get into film school to make movies. Movies about making movies are boring. Hard pass.
