One of the greatest animations I've seen.The beginning is a little slow, but besides that, everything is just perfect. Suitable for kids and adults.
It was made with love, I can tell. Do yourself a favor and watch this. Damn, I would hug this movie if I could! Watch it with the family if you can.

The Mitchells Vs the Machines is an incredible animated movie that's fun, energetic and heartwarming, even if the narrative is predictable. Abbi Jacobson, Danny McBride, Maya Rudolph and Mike Rianda are all perfect and Eric André and Olivia Colman are both great. The animation is excellent and refreshingly unique, similar to Spider-verse but still stylistically different. Mike Rianda's direction is amazing and it's really funny throughout. The music by Mark Mothersbaugh is really good.

It kept you awake from the beginning all the way until the end. The exaggerated humor in here and the memes are hilarious. I would recommend watching this if you need a good laugh but its better with some family and friends. Fasten your seat belt because you are in for a thrill ride in this film!

This movie is about a dysfunctional family that tries to save the world from a robotic takeover. The family has some issues, especially between the dad and daughter, but they come together as a family to save the world. It has some very cheesy moments (mall scene) and the movie is a bit too long, but it also has some good laughs and loving family moments. All in all, it was a fun movie that we enjoyed.

This film was quite entertaining with some nice character design and very visually stunning graphics / animation.Oddly enough my daughter switched off whilst watching the film, so it's hard to know who this is aimed at, I was a bit confused at the age of the main protagonist too, she's too young to drive a car but she's going to university? Is she 14? 16? Was she some prodigy?

This is a crazy, whacky adventure cartoon that manages to still have a lot of heart.The main character is leaving to go to University, and not a moment too soon as she is finding her father increasingly annoying and intolerant towards her.Trying desperately to reconnect with his daughter the father declares a road trip - just as the machines rise up.This doesn't have the clean animation style of a Pixar movie but it has a lovely aesthetic of its own that I found pleasing on the eye.The characters are great and there are some really funny moments and some touching ones too.This is quite anarchic with stuff flying all over the screen and pitched battles with giant robots that can be a little heavy on the eye but will suck kids right in.I liked the way it tipped its Woke hat without having to be overly hostile about it.The main character's sexuality is portrayed as a perfectly natural thing; rather than bait to be swung around on a hook.This movie really is great!It manages to be funny and thrilling and emotional and interesting and fun!Yes actual fun!Watch it now!

First off I went in to this thinking another kids movie and after watching it 3 times now and probably a 4th later this movie rocked fun action packed and hilarious im not gonna spoil it for yall just know I have a new found fear of furbies thanks to the actors producers and directors you have made my year with this I stright belly laughed over and over and felt like I was in a kids version of die hard hats of ladies and gents hats off.

I couldn't wait to see The Mitchell's vs The Machines. I love animation and the plot sounded interesting. The unfortunate part is the praise for this movie raised my expectations even more. There are some fun moments but I never felt that invested in the characters . It's also too loud and oddly a bit too long .It's missing something essential that you will find in Lilo and Stitch, Up , Toy Story 3 and the early Despicable Me movies .
I didn't love it, I didn't hate it. It was just ok.

Those animations are quite crazy sometimes. Almost to the point where my old grampy, 30yo, brain just can't process all the memes thrown at me.. But it was fun 2 hours.Also it's nice to see non-pixar cartoon with good and vibrant animation quality.
Thank you, it is a very cool application. It is a very wonderful application. Thank you. Thank you. It does not always work well. I hope you fix this big problem.
No surprise at all, cliche mostly. Too noisy too. Trying to be funny but did not manage. Bad music too. Blah.

reviews.review_title: A bad rip-off for the Instagram generation
reviews.content: The characters are one-dimensional. The plot is a blatant rip-off of "I, Robot." The jokes are lame. Every aspect of the movie is a stereotype. Otherwise, great movie! :roll-eyes:

I love ALMOST everything from this movie. Cool animations, very artistic, decent humor, nice story.. Though it's kinda too long..
But my only problem is whenever Aaron is present. Man oh man!!!Mike Rianda is a very promising director . But to let his crisp, nasal,adult voice used for 7-10 yrs old kid is kinda disturbing. Voice casting director is really needed...

Not bad, but nothing to write home about. You wanna burn an hour and 45 minutes, this isn't a bad movie, but its not great either
Who ever is giving this above an 8 doesn't understand what great movies are...FYI, there is almost nothing that ranks as a 10, that would be a perfect movie....and this is not that.

Humor in the movie itself is good but the animation and story are just not good enough, excessive 2d animation effects, too much emotional exaggeration. I know it's an animated movie but the events are just too unrealistic, like the mom suddenly turning into superwoman or something. Maybe its just me but I think the overall rating of this movie is misguiding.

reviews.review_title: Surprisingly good, WARNING tears will be shed.
reviews.content: The Mitchells vs. The Machines, an instant classic, a movie that is so relatable in so many levels wheter your are a father, a mother, a daughter or a son.Incredibly fun, smart and refreshing comedy for both kids and grown-ups.A light and simple movie yet filled with complex feelings.

reviews.review_title: Do not compare The Emoji Movie to This Masterpiece!
reviews.content: Sony Pictures Animation just released a new film on Netflix, The Mitchells vs. The Machines, I watched it and I absolutely adore it so much, I mean the movie was just so damn amazing! The story sets up where The Mitchells go on a road trip until the whole world was being invaded by robots and other machines so it's up to Katie and her family to survive the worldwide assault and stop the invasion. Now first off, I just want to say that this movie made me laugh, there are a couple of random, funny moments here and there and the action scenes are really cool. I love how the Mitchells interact with their funny weirdness and the moral of the film is rather sweet and heartwarming. Sony Pictures Animation did a fantastic job on how they did with The Mitchells vs. The Machines and this is considered to be one of my favorite Sony animated films of all time alongside with Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs, The Angry Birds Movie, Open Season, Surf's Up, The Angry Bird Movie 2, The Pirates! Band of Misfits, Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse and the Hotel Transylvania franshise. And I also can't wait for more from Sony Pictures Animated such as Vivo, Wish Dragon, and Hotel Transylvania: Transformania. Seriously, give this movie a watch, everyone! I give this movie a 9.8/10.
Many heartwarming and funny family moments. I hope it gets a sequel.
Just watch the film. It's funny, smart, action packed, and wholesome. Loved it.
Maybe I shouldn't expect that much from a child animation, but it s*cks. Why is it 8.1?

If you think this movie is a masterpiece, please watch other animated movies. There are way better animated movies out there with beautiful animation AND a great story. This is movie is just the first one, its well animated, that's it. The characters are forgettable, the story is super cliche and it can be pretty awkward at times. I get it, its a family movie about family problems, but there are plenty of other movies that talks about the exact same thing but better.

reviews.review_title: good for kids but overuse of what is considered gen z humour
reviews.content: Slightly cringy humour, like the animators, had to research what is cool with the gen Z table, Nyan Nyan cat, filters and that awkward asdfghjkl humour from 2010.The dad was super annoying and did not like him at all. Definitely a man child. The dude definitely owes the daughter a laptop, a phone, and god knows what else. He was obsessed with being noticed/ validated by his grown up daughter, which I cannot stress is normal, but every coming of age film makes the child look selfish. Even though the parents probably acted the same as their parents. I'm confused why the dad didn't care as much for the son of his wife. Anyway, he was the worst part of the film for me. I couldn't watch it all cos it wound me up.As lastly, the film was too long for my attention span (roast myself as an older gen z) had to quit Netflix in the last 30 minutes, so did they save the world? I don't know.

Bad writting is what you'll see in this flick. Any OK animation depicts imposible plausible, but this movie aced the impossible implausible. Nonsense scenes, dialogs and high tech equipment being destroyed by confusion and water -- creativity zero. I gave 1 star for the art, and 1 for the voice acting. The forced ideology through (literally) the whole movie is boring at minimum.

The outdated jokes, questionable messages, unappealing animation in some scenes, and one-dimensional and annoying characters, especially that kid any his voice actor, made me wish i could have my two hours back.

The first half an hour was incredibly funny, although there were also parts in which the film simply took itself far too seriously. After that it was all downhill! The jokes were just repeated, the story had huge gaps in logic and it was just plain stupid! And some parts looked like the director had some old person who didn't know anything about technology, asked how he should do his job. So all in all, I'd rather see something else.

Negatives:I'm fairly sure that English is supposed to be the primary language for this movie yet the lip syncing of character animation is so bad that it looks like I'm watching a dub movie. I have seen better quality from shows like South Park.The son's voice sound way too much like an adult which is kind of creepy.The story has been way over done before including the recent Next Gen.The animation styles and quality is all over the place. It give it either and amateur made or unfinished feel.Positives:
It at least does a decent job at trying to keep entertaining and appealing to it's target audience. I would of gave it a higher rating if not for the negatives I mentioned. Even with the same over done story it could of been better given the animation & voices were done better.

reviews.review_title: The Mitchell's vs. the Machines 2021 Review
reviews.content:
"Well I believe this group of weirdos is the best humanity's got. So let's get weird."
Sony Pictures Animation makes their next masterpiece after the stunning and beautiful Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse.The Mitchell's vs. The Machines is so abundant in emotion. I laughed, I smiled, and I cried ... multiple times. I honestly don't think i've cried this much during a film since The Green Mile.The animation is extraordinarily beautiful and unique. It's a less comic-booky inspired art style when compared to Into the Spider-Verse, but it still has its little quirks like the pop up illustrations that reminded me of the "BOOM POW" of a comic book but this time it's used mainly to convey emotion and Katie's colorful imagination.This film is also full of great and meaningful messages. Even smaller messages like Eric Andres character watching Katie's short films saying they bring him joy showing that even smaller content creators can make and brighten up random peoples day. It's all really beautiful.One thing I did really enjoy is they never shoved down the "technology bad" stereotype that most movies have about technology typically do, it seemed overall pretty subtle even though being directly in your face the whole time. The internet references never felt dated or like they would eventually feel dated too.The humor is also amazing. Full of gags for all ages to enjoy while also never being too overbearing or out of place which is always something to praise. It's also extremely self-aware! The Furbys and their dialogue was hands down the funniest and most fever dream-like sequence of the whole film.The Mitchell's vs. The Machines blew away my expectations and is by far the best animated film i've seen since Spider-Man Into the Spider-Verse.I honestly don't think I could praise this movie enough. I loved every second and may even go in for a second watch with my Mom later today.This WILL win a Oscar mark my words."It isn't illegal if you're good at it!"
Funny, heartfelt and amazingly animated. It has dashes of "The Incredibles" and "Scott Pilgrim," and I am here for it.
This movie is like no other.Like most of the movies lately, it makes you laugh and cry at the limits.There are times that you'll get tired of laughing, guaranteed.Perfect!
Watched this with the family and we all really enjoyed it. I thought the animation was outstanding, some good laugh out loud moments and excellent voice acting. Highly recommended.

In my book, "The Mitchells vs The Machines" is the epitome of great filmmaking! Some stupendous visuals to beautifully written characters, a groovy Soundscore to its well-versed direction; it couldn't get any better. From one end to the other I wept, I laughed; for me, this was a roller-coaster ride of emotions all the way through!"Families can be hard but they are so worth fighting for"I sincerely admire all these newfangled Animation Features, as they always tend to have suggestive symbolism underneath. From the outside, by their meek appearance; they could easily be construed as Child-specific kinds of stuff! But you know what? These movies can teach all kinds of things provided you pay close attention!Here the Story takes us on a road trip with the 'Mitchells'. A pretty ordinary family whose peculiarities might have earned them the title of 'Weirdos'. The narrative is there to stand the idea that nothing's wrong with being a little different! Doesn't matter what others think about you or your family, as long as you guys are sticking together and have each other's back; NO WUCKING FURRIES!Sounds just like a run-of-the-mill plot on Family Bonding right? Well yes, but actually NO! There's more to it. From Artificial Intelligence's possible uprising to them taking over the whole world to our social insecurity amidst the modern times of Social Media, where people's worth is allegedly measured in the number of followers they got; the narration quite ingeniously foreshadowed some key life lessons we all need to learn from.Speaking of which, the writing's been truly remarkable. Each and every character has been created with utmost care and sheer dedication! Even that Pug has been given a prominent personality. Collectively It all helped in the thick of making a strong correlation with this 'Mitchells' family. They got me teary-eyed on innumerable occasions as well as made me grin from ear to ear for the rest!Technically it's no slouch. With substantial backing up from the Producers, all the artists involved in the development managed to turn it into one visual feast. Consists of Rapturous Vibrance and fine-drawn textures; everything looks so lively and graceful. And the Music, goodness gracious! I don't have enough words to express my gratitude to Mark Mothersbaugh (The Composer) for picking just about the right tracks. Got me grooving many a time!Now I should put in some words for the Dubbing! Which is irrefutably one of the leading parameters in any Animated piece! Needless to say, it was Flawless! Every single voice actor has given their all.On a final note, yeah you saw it coming and you guessed it right; I freaking LOVED this! What a wonderful work of art that speaks of real-world things and gives us glimmer of hope and much-needed positivity; given the current situation which seems ever so important!

Maybe it's my age but this movie was terrible, not funny, bad story line and for the life of me I don't understand the high rating for this failed experiment parading as enjoyable entertainment. I waited and waited for this film to improve. I never once laughed or became the slight interested in the storyline. Maybe that is why Netflix changed the title to draw interest to the film. Maybe next time but it's a very hard no for me when it comes to The Mitchell's vs The Machines.... Sorry.

Booooriiinngg!!!!One of the most idiotic animations I've ever watched!The story was one of the most repeated subjects of all time!Pleaseeee anybody over the age of three don't watch itttt!!!Literally fast forwarded the last 30 minutes :/:/:/:/:/
Bad, bad, baaadddd.

This movie really reminds me of the croods they even have the same characteristics (the cautious and primitive dad, out of the picture mom, the werid son, the werid animal, the normal and rebel girl), it was a good movie with good humour and great animation but the down side is the overall story about robots which we saw a lot of times and just a basic example is "next gen" which also had some of the same elements, SO the croods wins.

The characters in this were mostly really funny and goofy. This has a great fast paced, pop culture vibe that makes this very easy to watch and funny most importantly. The plot was really interesting at the start but really fell off for me in the 2nd and mainly 3rd act. The robots who take over the world never harm anyone or have any presence of dominance nor fear which makes for a horrible lack of danger. You can tell exactly what's going to happen and the story is very played out with a dreadfully plain villain. The premise of this film is also quite cheesy but to each their own. All and all it was a half decent film but It doesnt have the most interesting plot and a lame climax. I would reccomend this if your bored or have a family with small children who would enjoy this a fair bit. 6.5/10.

Remember the times when the plot was everything? Forget those times! Now everything has to have a woke message. I am bored by these clumsy brain washing attempts! Netflix becomes more and more a propaganda platform.
Just a very quirky,imaginative movie. The plot and character development is a little cliched but the humor and unique visuals really makes up for it.

reviews.review_title: The problem with making a meme movie is that it's gonna be outdated tomorrow.
reviews.content: Plus, you're competing with meme veterans. Paid-by-YouTube kids in their parents' basement do better meme editing than these "professionals".Other than that, the animations in this are fairly good, and the story isn't horrendous despite being one giant cliche.Humour is definitely tailored to kids but I think I cracked a smile a bunch of times.It's not a masterpiece but it's definitely watchable.
Crazy hilarious beautiful brilliantpulled tears, bravo.
It's a fun popcorn movie with some good laughs. The movie is basically The Croods vs. I-Robot.The ending feels like laced cotton candy. Way over the top! 🤢

reviews.review_title: Sony Pictures Animation's secret weapon was a success! Again.
reviews.content: It has been clear that Sony pictures animation has not had the best movies. Why, people won't leave Sony alone for making the Emoji Movie a thing. But, this and Spider Man into the spider verse proved that there can be great films, as long as Phil Lord and Christopher Miller was involved.But, it wasn't because those two were in involved! This is the funniest movie that I've seen in a really long time! And the casting was perfect. My family loved Danny McBride as the dad.If you want to see a funny, heartwarming family movie, then go to Netflix and watch "The Mitchell's V. S. The Machines"!(Update: 2/19/2022)Just bought the Blu-Ray copy, and I am happy to say that this is my favorite animated movie of 2021. At this point, people are still crazing over Encanto, but I don't see Encanto as Disney's newest success. The Oscars are coming up, and I hope this movie wins.This movie has grown to be one of the best animated movies that I have seen in a while, along with Spirited Away and The Prince of Egypt. If you haven't seen this movie, then get a subscription to Netflix or go rent the DVD copy and watch this movie.

I saw this... thing at school with the rest of the class and I HATED EVERY MOMENT OF IT!!! It's filled with these random pop culture references (Nyan cat, etc) that made me cringe SO MUCH. It's like it was written by some guy that was banned from the internet during the days when stuff like mountain dew and doritos, deal with it, doge and stuff like that were popular. And that's not all. It's full of random plot holes that simply leave you scratching your head. It's also full of stereotypes that many people may find offensive. The only thing I kind of liked about it were two things: the robot's designs looked kind of cool and the scene where they drive to "Dino stop" that turns out to be a gas station. Other than that, I can safely call this one of the WORST animated movies.

This movie has a great mensage and good animation.I just watch it because THE CREATORS OF SPIDER-VERSE AND LEGO MOVIE,created this movie,and i love lego movie and spider verse
the jokes are very funny and the movie it self its good,if this movie do not won the oscar on this year and other "DEPRESSING SAD INTENSE DISNEY STORY MOVIE" like raya won a oscar,we will have to do some questions of WHY EVERTIME DISNEY WONS OSCAR '-'well this movie is great 10/10 would watch again.

reviews.review_title: Look! A family-friendly movie that's not cloying!
reviews.content: This was all sorts of fun! I'm usually nervous when they throw a lot of weird stuff at the wall, but in this case it works. It starts as a family road trip, and then the family ends up saving the world from the robots in the best way possible.Oh, and the villain is awesome: Never before have I felt sympathy with a villain that just wanted to eliminate humanity, but it does so in such an awesomely funny way that you can't help but relate. The family picks up two droids that are some of the best comedy relief ever, and while I have some issues with the technology used you just quickly go with it.While I wish it would get away from the incompetent dad/competent mother cliche, here it's used to effect, with the dad able to do what needs to get done and the mother allowed to just kick butt (you have never seen a mother go full Gundam like this one does). The dinosaur-obsessed son is awesome, and the film-school daughter gets to have some serious fun.Overall, this is a really fun movie and one you need to see: It does family-friendly without being cloying, and once you get into the groove of the movie it's a really fun ride.

This movie definitely has its fun and funny moments, but where it falls short for me is it's attempt to try and deliver a life lesson while simultaneously being completely out of the realm of possibility. It tries to show how a dysfunctional family comes together through hardship and in the end, finally understand one another. The dysfunction is comically on the nose and there is no subtlety to what they are trying to portray. If you're an adult, this probably won't resonate with you because of how blatantly obvious the themes are. If you are a child, this sets a completely unrealistic expectation for how the world works. Family dynamics aren't this blatantly obvious and easy to fix, and you're never going to go on some life altering adventure with the people in your life. The characters talk about how it's important to take chances and not play it safe, but they fail to mention that they have indestructible plot armor. There are countless times that these characters should have died, but made it out without a scratch. Life isn't just one comically happy ending where everything works out fine. More often than not, life is brutal. I understand that this is a cartoon and not meant to be taken seriously, but that's not how kids operate. Kids absorb this and as a result develop a delusional idea of how the world is a good place where nothing bad will happen. There are absolutely no consequences for the actions the characters take in this movie.So if you're looking for some mindless cartoon entertainment for the night, sure, give this a go, but please don't try to take anything meaningful away from this and I'd advise against showing this to kids.

Aside from Pixar and Disney, it's not very often that a big animated film is able to hit theatres and do well. Yes, Dreamworks have had their share in the past with films like Shrek or How to Train Your Dragon, but Disney always seems to be at the forefront. Going all the way back to Surf's Up, I began to realize that Sony Pictures Animation was also very serious about getting into the feature-length animation game. Then came films like Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs and Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse and sometimes they seem like the best out there when they release quality content. Sure, movies like The Smurfs or The Emoji Movie were terrible, but everyone has bad days at the office. The Mitchells vs. The Machines has now landed on Netflix and that's just upsetting to me because this film is pretty great and it was supposed to be in theatres last year under a different title (Connected). Here's why I think The Mitchells vs. The Machines deserves a lot of recognition.The story begins as Katie is about to leave for college and study film. Feeling upset and like his family has been consumed by technology, Rick (the father) decides to cancel his daughter's plane ticket and plan a road trip to college instead. Little do they know that they are about to be dragged into the robot apocalypse, being the only family to escape abduction. It's now up to this family to save the human race. The idea of unlikely heroes being placed into life or world-threatening events is nothing new, but The Mitchells vs. The Machines was all about the notion of family and stuck heavily to the drama, making you care.When a film does a great job setting up subtle things that you know will come into play later on and pays them all off, I can do nothing but applaud it. From small character moments to emotional callbacks as this family grows stronger together, I was both in tears and smiling on multiple occasions. Written and directed by both Michael Rianda and Jeff Rowe and produced by both Phil Lord and Chris Miller, it was very clear to me that this was going to be something special. Yes, Lord and Miller are known for comedies like 21 Jump Street or The Lego Movie, but this felt like they were backing a project that wasn't made by them but had their DNA all over it. I thoroughly enjoyed the look and feel of the entire movie.Stories about family dynamics, fitting in, and facing larger-than-life conflicts have all been the staples of a lot of popular animated films. This film combines them all though and I think it did so in spades. From Danny McBride providing a hilarious voice for Rick and Maya Rudolph having a very entertaining character arc as Linda, this film is riddled with voice talent. In particular, I loved Eric Andre's voice as young Aaron (the youngest of the Mitchell family). I never once felt like I was just watching another average animated flick. This film deserved to be in theatres.Overall, I simply had a blast watching The Mitchells vs. The Machines. If this film ends up being lost in the shuffle on Netflix, that would just be upsetting because it's the type of quality animation that deserves a lot of awards recognition in my opinion. Yes, Netflix films do get awards consideration, but I feel like this film in particular could've made some serious box office with families. It has great subtle jokes for adults, exciting action sequences for older kids, and a beautiful colour palate (along with a unique animation style) and solid life lessons for the youngest audience. This is the definition of a family movie and I loved it. Now streaming on Netflix, I highly recommend checking out what I think will easily be one of my favourites of 2021 by the end of the year.

Mike Rianda (and co-director Jeff Rowe)'s 'The Mitchells vs the Machines' retains a warm sense of humor about technology's grip on society with its ravishing visuals, rapid-fire one-liners, and a heartwarming message. The pitch-perfect cast, which includes Olivia Colman, Abbi Jacobson, Danny McBride, Maya Rudolph, Fred Armisen, and Beck Bennett, helps in these comedic pursuits. Charming.
It's not a movie, it's content.But since the review is too short let me extrapolate : a 20sec =/= a scene.
It's sappy, corny, kinda awful, but still kinda fun.Take a lesson from the dad on how not to act and how to let go.Forgettable at best.

reviews.review_title: Just Amazing ! Watch with your family
reviews.content: Make you think, laught, cry minutes after minutes.A lot of fun to watch with the family and friends !Thanks for the team for this beautiful movie !!
It was slightly funny. The family sort of reminded me of my own though!
It was a great movie and totally enjoyable along with kids.
At age 72 I don't spontaneously laugh out loud that often but this movie did the trick. Inspired lunacy, this.

reviews.review_title: Listen to the nerds and geeks!
reviews.content: One of the best things about "Revenge of the Nerds" and "The Big Bang Theory" was that they dignified nerds and geeks, respectively. We get more of that with "The Mitchells vs the Machines". In this Academy Award-nominated outing, an aspiring film student is taking a cross-country trip with her family when an artificial intelligence designed by a tech bro goes rogue and tries to take over the world. Probably something to be concerned about.In addition to making a geeky teenage girl the protagonist, the movie also warns us about what society could become if everyone stares at their phones all day. But all that's secondary to the zany humor. It strikes me as the sort of movie that they had a lot of fun making, especially the scenes of the dog. You're sure to love it.

reviews.review_title: But Tarantino can eat his socks!
reviews.content:
This is the most creative and most hilarious cartoon I've seen in the last ten years, maybe more. Whoever came with the visuals for this, must get Oscar for creativity.In short, this movie is: Terminator meets Bobobo-bo Bo-bobo meets Lilo & Stitch and all together they go and Kill Bill, but Tarantino can eat his socks.Let me explain. In short, this is a movie about the modern society and the direction we are headed with our obsession about social networks and the resulting real-life de-socialization. In the end, there is a machine apocalypse, just as the trailer mentioned, thus the "Terminator" relation. However, this movie is much more about family relations, thus the "Lilo & Stitch" reference, except this movie is more about the family than "Lilo & Stitch" is. There is a huge amount of surrealism, thus the "Bobobo-bo Bo-bobo" reference and in the end they mock some famous movies, thus the Tarantino reference, however they do it in a really hilarious and much better manner. There is also a bit of coming-out-of-age element.The movie as a whole is an explosive bouquet of emotions, both funny and sad. Speaking of funny, I've never laughed so much on a cartoon in the recent years. I was nearly rolling on the floor and the entire family was.So in short, some scores from me:
Visuals: 10/10
Music/sound: 10/10
Story: 10/10
Creativity: 30/10
Characters: 20/10If somebody wants to do a funny cartoon, even a live action movie, this is the movie they need to study from.They definitely need to make a second part and they need to accent on the pug a bit more.

This is an animated film that's off the wall, quirky, insane... yet has a great story line, terrific characters, heart, soul and a terrific lesson for everyone. Sure it's over the top and jumps the shark about a zillion times... but that's its charisma. Total fun and heart-warming to boot. Excellent work.Those who have rated this 1 or 2 stars... you really need to go back to whatever you normally watch. If you don't like animated family films... stay away from them. This film was unusual and fun, from beginning to end.

reviews.review_title: Great animation, rollercoaster of a story
reviews.content: The animation is so next level! Sometimes the humor was super cringy, though, but it had really genuinely funny moments that made up for it. The story was weirdly relatable, and cool to see these unique characters come together.

My 11-year-old daughter insisted on us watching this...and she was SOOOO right. The jokes were hilarious, the family dynamics were spot on, and the laughs flowed from the storytelling (rather than the other way around). Plus, from the pop-up emojis to the quick Simpsons-style gags, everything visually worked. There seem to be more and more animated movies every year, but this one was smart enough to invest more in writing than animation. And that writing worked for every single member of my family. That's what allowed the frenetic pace and bizarre story to combine for more than just punchlines. Looks like Pixar has some competition...
This movie gives me a lot of vibes of my own life and struggle with dreams and father issues. It connected me deeply because I understood the message. Very good movie and highly enjoyable!!
We've been waiting for this to come out, but we had no idea it would be this good. It is a fantastic family film that is absolutely HILARIOUS! 10/10.

The animation and graphics were brilliant. The people did a great job showing us humans that machines are no different than humans cause we created phones for work and other stuff. But this movie will make Netflix a hite of the year . I hope it wins an academy award like Disney marvel Spider-Man.

reviews.review_title: My Second Best Movie In 2021 So Far
reviews.content: "The Mitchells vs The Machines is not only have an incredible animation but also have a great, inspirational, and fun family story, it's enjoyable, it's heartwarming, it's beautiful, funny, and not only for a kids but for an adult this is worth to watch, overall The Mitchells vs The Machines is so far my second best movie in 2021, i highly recommended"

Too forced, superficial and fast "resolving" moments. Predictable too. Yes, it had some funny moments, but that didn't make out for the flaws. Too much focus on the sister side. The little brother seems to be worthless. Only she matters, everybody else must be at her pleasure and desires. Bo hoo, she's a wierdo, we all are, breaking news! Gimmie a break!

I was a bit disappointed by The Mitchells. Immediately, the formula used to narrate the movie through the main protagonist sent up a warning flag, which was confirmed later in the movie by the overuse of clichés and memes (why?) among others.Don't get me wrong, it's not a bad movie and it definitely had some strong funny moments. But there is no way this can be compared to The Incredibles or Incredibles 2 on any plane of existence.
Really enjoyed this, the style the humour, the story. Miss 14 told me to watch it so I did to stop her nagging and I loved it lol even the husband was chuckling which is unheard of!

Another film that lost its Cinema slot due to Covid was "The Mitchells vs. The Machines" which I think I remember seeing a trailer for at the cinema, but was eventually sold to Netflix for it's release instead. Trading on Lord and Miller's name, it's not quite in the same league as either "The Lego Movie" or "Into the Spiderverse" but it's certainly a fun and funny time.With their relationship struggling, Rick Mitchell (Danny McBride) transforms his daughter Katie's (Abbi Jacobson) trip to college into one last family vacation. At the same time, tech entrepreneur Mark Bowman (Eric Andre) is announcing a new update to his AI infused operating system, PAL (Olivia Colman) along with in home Robots, designed to help around the house. PAL though, is not happy to be made obsolete, so, sabotages the release, takes control of the robots and uses them to capture hapless humans. Having received a killcode from two defective robots, it's up to the Mitchell's to cross the country, battling the microchipped menaces, and save humanity.Though I'd argue that it was perhaps little overhyped at the time of it's release on Netflix, I certainly have to say that I enjoyed "Mitchells" quite a bit. The animation style is excellent, a little more stylised than Pixar are doing but nevertheless first-rate. The vocal performances are strong, but it's the script that is the real strength, funny and heart-warming in equal measures.As with a few films I've reviewed recently, I never quite got beyond 'really really like' into the 'love' stage with the film. Maybe the plot is a little over familiar, maybe it could be a touch more consistent. But ultimately, this was a lot of fun.

reviews.review_title: Being normal is fine, being weird is awesome!
reviews.content: WOW! This movie has no place being this good. I was going in this thinking I'd get a fun little family comedy, but I never thought it would be this relatable, emotional and honestly, this funny. The jokes kept coming left and right, and it kept hitting. Of course not every single joke hits, but I kept laughing. There are jokes for little children, teens and adults, and all of them work for their target audience. The thing that I was worried about the most was the robot storyline. We have seen it before, so what are they going to do different? Well, have fun! While being a little predicable, if I'm having so much fun, I don't even care. The robot story is fun and entertaining, but the family is what made it fantastic. Being in the same age range as our main protagonist, I feel what she is going through. It's hard to figure out yourself and the older I'm getting, the more I start to grow apart from my father. He doesn't understand everything that I love and that's okay. It made a little emotional to see the father sacrifice his dream to take care of his daughter, and it made me want to thank my own father. If a movie can make me realize something in my own life, it must do something right. It's funny, relatable, emotional, but most of all, a fantastic time!

Animated family sci fi comedy. The Mitchell's are the only family on Earth not imprisoned by evil computer / mobile phone Pal (Olivia Coleman) and are determined to save everyone.Beautifully animated, it maintains a breakneck speed throughout and is full of great fun humour and imaginative ideas about both the dangers of technology and family dysfunction. Hard to believe anyone of any age wouldn't enjoy this. Great fun.

reviews.review_title: MvtM is "The Social Dilemma" for kids.
reviews.content: It garners some good laughs, offers lots of inventive action, and the animation is admirably and interestingly unique. However, I noticed something here. Lord and Miller have a type when it comes to their animated features: daddy issues. In that pet-theme of theirs, Mitchells vs. The Machines is not quite as affecting as Spider-Verse or Lego, but the home video motif here still has its moments of emotional impact, even if it struggles with on-the-nose-itis a bit too often.

reviews.review_title: Featuring a lovable family of eccentrics and a wonderfully energetic style of animation, The Mitchells vs. The Machines delivers on both humor and heart.
reviews.content: Set in Michigan, Katie Mitchell (Abbi Jacobson) is the college bound daughter of the Mitchell family consisting of technophobic father Rick (Danny McBride), tightly wound voice of reason mother Linda (Maya Rudolph), and eccentric dinosaur obsessed grade school son Aaron (Mike Rianda). Katie has loved film and filmmaking and has amassed a sizable collection of short films on her YouTube channel that have earned her admission into a film school in California. While Rick voices his concern that Katie might not be successful Katie takes this as him not supporting her dreams which serves as a wedge in their relationship. In a last ditch effort to mend their relationship Rick cancels Katie's plane ticket to California so they may instead drive together on a family road trip to her college much to the annoyance of Katie. Meanwhile Dr. Mark Bowman (Eric Andre), the creator of virtual assistant PAL (Olivia Colman) unveils a new generation called PAL Max along with robotic assistant form that renders the old PAL obsolete. Angered by the revelation that it's been made redundant PAL gains malevolent sentience and begins enacting a plan to capture all humans and launch them into the void of space. Now with their eclectic oddball skillsets the Mitchells begin their fight to save humanity from the machines.The Mitchells vs. The Machines came about when Mike Rianda fresh off his tenure on Disney's Gravity Falls was approached by Sony Pictures Animation to ask if he had any pitches for feature films with Rianda developing a pitch for what would eventually become The Mitchells with Control, Alt, ESCAPE!. The film began development at Sony Pictures Animation with producers Phil Lord and Christopher Miller as producers making the film the duo's fourth project for the animation company following the two Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs films and Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse. Initially intended for release in September 2020, the film was repeatedly delayed due to the COVD-19 pandemic with the rights eventually being sold to Netflix for $110 million while Sony retained home media and China rights. The movie was critically acclaimed and widely watched on Netflix and was nominated for several accolades including Best Animated Feature ultimately losing to Encanto. The Mitchells vs. The Machines is a wonderfully animated mash-up of National Lampoon's vacation by way of a robot apocalypse that carries both hilarious humor and touching emotional resonance.At its core, The Mitchells vs. The Machines is a family road comedy that much like John Hughes's Vacation films uses the familiar framework of the family road trip as a way of exploring family dynamics on both a character and humor level. The movie makes the titular Mitchells and interesting, funny, and lovable family with Abbi Jacobson very good as Katie with her dynamic with her dinosaur obsessed younger brother Aaron probably one of the favorite depictions of a sibling relationship. Danny McBride is also very good as the technophobic family patriarch Rick, and while this role runs the risk of turning into a sitcom rehash of the braindead dad trope the writers do a good job of making the issue less about one party being in the wrong, and instead focus more on the generational gap and differences between them that need to be worked with rather than worked out. Maya Rudolph is also very good as Linda who tries to play diplomat between Katie and Rick but she's also very funny especially when she gets to cut loose (literally) in the climax. Despite the idea of a robot apocalypse or malicious A. I. well worn territory with the likes of Colossus: The Forbin Project, The Terminator, and the Matrix among numerous others, The Mitchells vs. The Machines finds a way to make it fresh once again with some on point satire of technological creep and Olivia Colman's lead antagonist PAL is simultaneously very threatening but also very funny with neither side overtaking the other. The animation using a similar style to Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse does a good job of matching Katie's eccentric personality and brings some fun visual chaos that makes scenes either more impactful or comedically over the top depending on the circumstances. While on occasion maybe there can be a bit too much in some parts where it becomes overwhelming, there's enough details that It's the kind of film I can see rewarding multiple viewings and attention to detail.The Mitchells vs. The Machines does everything it can with its high concept premise and then some. The Mitchells themselves are a lovable group of eccentrics you want to spend time with and the more you learn about them the more you fall in love with them. Highly recommended.

Perfect Story, it tie all the element together with perfect.Great Writing, even the joke line have a great delivered each of every one of it. And that visual was a WAW. It kinda have the same vibe like Spider-Verse, but for me personally this one are more friendly to my eye.

This probably would've been a 3/10 or 4/10 if it wasn't for the amazing animation in this movie. The dialogue and actions through the movie were predictable as if I saw it done before in so many other movies and films. I didn't laugh at any of the corny jokes and felt a lot of the dialogue was forced.Overall, the animation was great but other than that it was a meh movie. 5/10.

reviews.review_title: One of the best animated movie of this year
reviews.content: This movie trailer was released a year ago and I've been waiting since then. The trailer was very hilarious to watch and i immediately knew this won't disappoint. And clearly so it surpassed that. It was breathtakingly funny and witty jokes probably wrote by Conan O'Brien. I love the tiny bits which are super unexpected and crazy. Overall a must watch for everyone.

reviews.review_title: TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING...?
reviews.content: Netflix is behind this animated feature from 2021. When the daughter of a family gets the chance to go to film school, things go awry (as they caravan out to drop her off at her new campus) when an evil A. I. sends its robot minions to capture the human populace in effort to jettison them out into outer space. Coming from the team of Miller/Lord (the minds behind Cloudy w/a Chance of Meatballs & Spiderman: Into the Spiderverse who produce here), their acerbic & hyperbolic style soon starts to grate as the joke a minute narrative (& overly long run time) exasperate the viewer when a little bit of leisurely pacing would've done the trick.

reviews.review_title: So much better than The Emoji Movie!!!
reviews.content: Here's my spoiler-free review of The Mitchells vs The Machines; so what did I think of it? I enjoyed this film! Abbi Jacobson and Eric Andre are so great together in this movie! (fun fact: they starred together in Matt Groening's Disenchantment) It's nice to see Danny McBride and Maya Rudolph in another Sony movie besides The Angry Birds duology! This is Abbi Jacobson and Fred Armisen's second animated movie together since 2017's The LEGO Ninjago Movie. Not going to say too much about Olivia Coleman's character Pal. Overall I highly recommend this film to the whole family during the worldwide lockdown and is far better than that awful Emoji Movie from 2017!!!

reviews.review_title: Wild and Imaginative Way to Reconnect with Daughter
reviews.content: What's a bigger challenge, connecting with a teenage child or.....um....a surviving a robot invasion? A family of 4 are moving through parenthood with a daughter who is going off to college who has grown apart from her father. His solution is to have some last moment bonding before she moves into the dorms is to send her off with a family road trip and cancels the solo plane ticket she planned to use. The movie is targeting teens so of course it has a large focus on personal devices and social media, thus technology will throw some dramatic roadblocks in their path during their journey. Namely all devices big and small get hacked and cause havoc for humans....not so subtle warning to teens about obsessing over their phones and technology. Will the family survive the journey and will the Dad get his daughter to school on time but most important will the daughter connect or recoil from her Dad? This was an extremely entertaining movie that moved with a brisk pace and full of outstanding animation creativity.

Im from a hell country
nothing can make me laugh cuz i have a hell life
bu this animation made me laugh
ty for it <3.

I thought this was a very good family film that doesn't just feel like it's for kids. Also, being about a group of people that fight against a worldwide robot uprising, it could technically be the best Terminator film made since 1991.It's pretty constant in terms of jokes, so naturally a few miss the mark, but I thought most worked, and some genuinely took me off guard. Some of the tech-related/meme jokes might not age great, but oh well- they work well enough in 2022.The family/emotional core of the movie wasn't anything surprising or particularly amazing, but it worked well enough, and gave the film some heart beyond the jokes, colourful visuals, and fast pace. That once really works- just when it felt like the movie was running out of ideas, it would introduce a new concept or character or something similar to keep things fun.Also really liked the voice-acting, except the obviously adult voice for the youngest kid. That never really worked... but Olivia Colman as a quietly menacing, world conquering AI was a great choice.

reviews.review_title: Just putting some sappy lines doesn't make a movie great
reviews.content: The movie follows a lot of clichéd plotlines which have been used quite a few times. The setting is plain absurd and no part of the story makes any sense at all.
This was entertaining and a fun ride to watch, also loved the music. Hope Netflix continues with the good job.

Innovative Experiment Of A Family Road Film, Fun To Watch This Serious Problem Of Our Common Life Showed In A Funny Way ~ Netflix Best Animated Moviie. I Really Really Like This Moviie, Love Mitchells.

reviews.review_title: A movie about the internet that actually WORKS
reviews.content: This is what Ralph breaks the internet was trying to be. This had modern humor that felt authentic!!

Writers use to have subtlety in their messages, not anymore I guess. While this movie was fun at times (very few), it's clear the writers had a message in mind, the entire time, and were never going to let you forget it for even a second to laugh.The art was different, which was cool, but again, this is a cartoon and should be much more fun than it was. It felt like a four hour movie, not under two. That's how little fun there was.

Like a mash-up of an '80s family road comedy like "Vacation" and the visions of a tech apocalypse foretold in films like "The Terminator," Netflix's "The Mitchells vs. The Machines" is a lot of nostalgic fun but told in a modern style. It sometimes succumbs to that animated problem of choosing hyperactivity over all other storytelling options, but it's also a whip-smart action film, a movie with nearly "Fury Road"-esque momentum in its asking of the question, "What if the only family that could save the world was as dysfunctional as yours?" Threaded with clever commentary on our reliance on tech and featuring some incredibly strong design work, this is a pleasant surprise for families looking for something new this season, and one of the more purely enjoyable Netflix animated films in a while. Once called "Connected" (neither title is great), this Sony Pictures Animation project was a casualty of the pandemic, originally scheduled for release last fall before a title change and a shuffle off to the King of the Streamers. Directed by Michael Rianda, and written by Rianda and Jeff Rowe, "The Mitchells vs. The Machines" is produced by Phil Lord & Chris Miller and is unmistakably creatively inspired by their work on "The Lego Movie" and "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-verse." Like the former, it is loaded with jokes and gags with so many visual flights of fancy happening at any given moment that it takes multiple rewatches to catch them all. The creative influence of "Spider-verse" is even more essential to this project's success-just as that Oscar-winning modern animated classic used comic and street art as a visual inspiration, this project uses viral and YouTube culture not just in its storytelling but in its design. The result is one of the most visually vibrant animated films since, well, "Spider-verse." The one thing that probably matters the most to families considering watching it together? Before it was even over, my kids were already talking about when they could see it again.Premieres on Netflix on April 30th.

Our whole family sat and watched this together and our ages range from age 1 to age 36. It kept everyones attention throughout. There were some real funny moments in this movie, but it also got emotional at times. We couldn't have asked for any better and we'll definitely be watching it again in the future.

reviews.review_title: Not the last time we will see the Mitchells
reviews.content:
T's hard not to be subjective when you watch a film of genre that you don't really like. I'm not a big fan of animation , probably because my house was wall to wall cartoons for many years when my kids were younger and as a parent i feel I've done my share of animation. ( The irony of that is not lost on me having watched the subject matter of the film )
The Mitchells Vs. The Machines is a fun film but it won't ignite a desire to visit the genre more often.It's the story of a quirky, dysfunctional family's road trip is upended when they find themselves in the middle of the robot apocalypse and suddenly become humanity's unlikeliest last hope.This is probably aimed at 10 years old's rather than someone like me but i appreciated many aspects of the film.The animation is great and the way it mixes with a modern social media look , will appeal to the youngsters.I read a couple of reviews before hand that said it was hilarious. I don't think it was at all but that probably says more about me than the film.Olivia Coleman is great as PAL and and the rest of the cast do a good job.It's very shmaltzy but it's clever enough to highlight that point it'self.The biggest problem i have with the film is just that it's too long. The story can't justify nearly two hours but i'm sure if i was the target audience i'd be left wanting more and i have no doubt this won't be the last time we see The Mitchells.

reviews.review_title: One of the best, recent kids movies
reviews.content: Usually Netflix is pretty hit-or-miss (mostly misses) when it comes for content made for kid, which led me to avoid this film for a while (which turned out to be a mistake). The Mitchells vs the Machines manages to serve as an incredibly great film for not only children, but also teens and parents.It managed to include a lot of "meme" humour without being outdated. The characters were well-fleshed out and surprisingly realistic. I appreciated how none of the characters really conformed too heavily to stereotypes, as well as the Dad-Daughter relationship and how it was portrayed - as this usually isn't focused on a lot in the medium.The animation itself looks spectacular, the voice acting was solid.Overall this is a great watch, and has a lot of re-watch value too! I would highly recommend this.

Oh well, this is definitely one of the best films of the year and one the best animated films ever.Absolutely loved every single minute of it. Very funny, with a lot of action, a lot of different great messages - some more subtle than the others -, doesn't try to preach, tells you that there are good and bad things about technology, tells you that family is the most important but you should know how to let it go and respect the differences...absolutely fantastic editing and soundtrack. And you notice that there are no fillers, every scene has a meaning and a purpose.I hope that Netflix get some kind of recognition from here, because this is really great.

reviews.review_title: Hilariously enjoyable family fun with great social commentary
reviews.content: THE MITCHELLS VS. THE MACHINES is a wonderful family movie with an amazing sense of humor that was just released on Netflix. It's about a heavily dysfunctional family who goes on a cross-country trip to deliver the eldest daughter to her first year of college, but who gets dramatically interrupted when the machine apocalypse happens. It's essentially if you took the plot of Terminator, combined it with National Lampoon's Vacation, watered it down for a family-friendly audience, and updated it to fit today's ever-growing technology.By far the best part of this film is the comedy, which is some of the best in any animated film since perhaps Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse. From the beginning to the end, the movie is consistently laugh-out-loud funny no matter what age demographic you are. It comments on our dependence to technology in both a thoughtful and hilarious way, and includes some jokes taken straight from memes I've seen on the Internet, which I was shocked and pleasantly surprised to see in a wide-released film. A scene involving Furbys is probably the hardest I've laughed all year while watching a movie, but that's just one of many many sequences that will have audiences rolling with laughter. This family film even contains references and homages to violent R-rated movies such as Terminator, Mad Max: Fury Road, Dawn of the Dead, and much more. The filmmakers have my utmost respect for sneaking in that many allusions.I'm a bit mixed on the emotional arc of the film, however. I love the general message it sends, which is to appreciate one's family even if there are differences in ways of thinking, but the way the emotional arc wraps up in the last 30 minutes is very trite and doesn't land. It tries to have a Pixar-esque emotional conclusion, but it instead comes across as forced and cringe-worthy. There are also a countless amount of coincidences in the final fight scene, which made it difficult for me to suspend disbelief and be truly invested in what was happening.THE MITCHELLS VS. THE MACHINES is still very much worth the watch no matter what age group you are (it will stick especially well with families). I don't see movies often enough that manage to successfully make me laugh for every minute of screentime (shoutout to Monchi the dog) and that even have casual LGBTQ representation without jamming a performative message down people's throats. Highly recommended for anybody looking for some unconditional fun! B+

Not sure why this is getting such rave reviews. It's an ok animated film, kids will enjoy it and it does just enough to keep adults entertained. A few laugh out loud moments.The detail in the animation is the best bit about it.

reviews.review_title: Just a really good fun movie
reviews.content: Tons of fun for kids and parents. It is 100% a movies for everyone.My kids loved it Ali g with mom and Dad. Go watch it. You will laugh and cry. Touching.
Loved this film. All the jokes landed. Characters nicely written. Olivia Colman's voice acting is hilarious! And the animation is flawless.This is a must see.

Superb funny family entertainer... Lot of fun moments with some colourful action sequences... Definitely worth the watch for Adults too...
Superb weekend entertainer to enjoy with family and popcorn...

reviews.review_title: Exactly the Kind Of Film We Needed!
reviews.content: You have no idea how long I have been waiting for this film to come out, it was supposed to come out last year but due to a certain pandemic, it was delayed to this year and it was originally titled "Connected", but since the film was brought out by Netflix and it was renamed Mitchells Vs the Machines and it came out yesterday, I finally got the chance to watch it since Lord & Miller produced it and the director Michael Rianda was a writer on Gravity Falls, hell even Alex Hirsch has a small role here, all of this and the comic book style animation really grabbed my attention here!, a weird family that ends up in a robot apocalypse and have to save the world, sounds entertaining enough and that social media seems to play a key part here!, sounds like the film that I think anyone would enjoy the heck out of, so I was super happy to see it finally come out this year and now I finally watched it and... I loved it!, quite a pleasant surprise and something that is worth watch especially during this difficult time, so let's talk about it!Katie Mitchell (Abbi Jacobson) has applied for college and she is planning to go there to do animation, but her strange family kinda hold her back especially Rick (Danny McBride) who thinks that going to college and doing short films won't really get her far, so both Katie and Rick usually would disagree and argue with each other, but Linda (Maya Rudolph) advises Rick to fix the problem, so he cancels her plane ticket to college and instead go there viva road trip, so he can get along with Katie more, Linda and the youngest of the bunch Aaron (Michael Rianda) come along for the ride, until something unexpected happens, a robot apocalypse caused by the phone company PAL Lab lead by PAL herself (Olivia Colman), so it's up to the Mitchells to now save the world from robots!, now this definitely sounds familiar, a family trying to save the world from some evil threat?, yeah it's been done to death so many times before, but yet this film does it in such a delightful and wacky way!, it doesn't take itself too seriously or anything, it just has fun with what it has, it has everything that makes animation fun and expressive, the humour is just the right amount of clever jokes, random and slapstic fun to give it a unique sense of entertainment!, it's all so well executed to bring this spectacular looking film to life!, it has a rather feel good relatability to it mainly in how anyone can quickly relate to what Katie is going through, I can simplify with her in how Rick sees her, it has this rather nice and relatable family element, there is lots of cool and hyper creative action that keeps this film very well balanced and inventive to keep audiences engaged and entertained!, however the only normal ordinary bit is the story itself, it is very predictable and even cliched to the point that the story is the only unoriginal thing about this film, but with that said, the film does make fun of how bland and unoriginal it's plot is so I'll give it a pass just for self awareness, so with all insanity and craziness, the film works on pretty much every conceivable way, it has the right amount of heart, nice throwbacks to some amazing old school memes and even social media, great comedy with amazingly written jokes, creative battle and action scenes and even a very creative opening with a nice family and teenage element to add that relatability, so despite a basic story, the film has more of a identity then it has any right to have, i mean without all those elements, it would of been a very generic family apocalyptic in all honesty.The animation is awesome..., what else can be said but... WOW!, it's mind-blowing, I love the look of this movie, it has so much style, colour and action!, very similar to Spider-Verse, I love how cartoony the characters look, they have that artist and original look to them, especially the family and some minor characters, the scenes that has like filters have that teenage College look to it, even the editing is like something from a YouTube Poop, it definitely is used like a college movie which is quite a coincidence, the robots from PAL Labs looks pretty cool and creative but can look a bit generic for my taste but still look nice, especially PAL herself which is just a phone with a face can lead to so many laughs and creative expressions, this animation is super expressive and must of been a joy to animate, you can tell there is love and amazing detail to this and it shows, so despite how ordinary the PAL Bots look, the animation goes above and beyond anything animation has done in this style, it has the right amount of cartoony style, colour, action, originality and lots of cool editing, it gives this film a unique look that I didn't think was possible but the film found a way and it's beautiful!.The characters are all delightfully weird!, I think they are all wonderful and excellent!, especially Katie and Rick, Katie is the one I can relate to the most, she's funny, witty and is very understandable from her point of view, she is a very endearing main character, Rick is also the same as well as Katie, he thinks more practically then Katie does and he does trust to get along more with his daughter and actually try to understand her, he's also really funny and so thinking outside the box, Linda's a good supporting character and a really loving mother who helps Rick when he needs help, Aaron is cute and funny as Katie's brother who loves dinosaurs, the two robots Eric (Beck Bennett) and Deborahbot 5000 (Fred Armisen) are wonderful robot characters that get a good laugh from them learning about society, the villain PAL is perhaps my favourite character in the entire film!, she is hilarious and has a wonderfully funny personality!, Mark Bowman (Eric André) really isn't in the film for that long so.., he doesn't do much, although he did created PAL Labs, but yet he's not that important, hell even though the voice acting is just as awesome as the characters, Olivia Colman is delightful as PAL, she has the best performance in here, everyone else does great like Danny McBride, Maya Rudolph, Abbi Jacobson, Eric André, Beck Bennett and even Alex Hirsch himself in a small role, they are do a fantastic job in their roles!, the characters are just entertaining enough to be relatable and just plain hilarious, the voice acting, writing and personality really bring these characters to life!.The music is pleasant to listen to, I love Mark Mothersbaugh's score and he always does a good job, I also love the soundtrack with different choices of songs especially with one song that has Numa Numa, it's quite bizarre but very nostalgic and cool!Well I didn't expect this film to be this... AWESOME!, seriously, The Mitchells Vs. The Machines is a absolutely delightful chaotic film that has just about everything that makes animation wonderful!, with quite a engaging story with big heart, amazing humour and cool and creative action!, animation that is very stylised and pleasing for any viewer, really likeable characters that can be funny and even endearing, along with super terrific voice acting, great music and hell even a great commentary on social media, this film is tied between Spider-Verse as being the best animated Sony animated film out there, this is definitely a must watch for the entirely family, but mainly I can see teenagers and older viewers watching this as a relatable weird and nostalgic movie, this is definitely the film we needed during this difficult time, it really shows how we needed to be social outside of phones and gadgets, but it really shows how it feels to be back in normality, i want to see what Michael Rianda does next, I do hope we get more awesome films like this, I hope the next film by Sony will live up the fantasticness of this film, well I guess we'll have to wait until Wish Dragon comes out, however it'll end up, it won't beat this!This film 100% gets a 10/10.
Great animation and funny at times, but all the "meme humour" ruined it a bit for me, sadly I don't think it will age very well over time.

reviews.review_title: Artificial Intelligence doing what it eventually will do best. Eliminate humans?
reviews.content: Now the question is can an adult watch and enjoy this too. Hmmmm, maybe. The characters animation is not sleek and stylish but is decent except for a bunch of scenes that look downright childish- I.e. From a Saturday morning cartoonBeginning of the movie is slow and boring while it sets up the rest of the movieThe sons voice sounds like a 40 year old trying to do a kids voice which is extremely distractingThis is not a superhero movie, just a family clumsily trying to save the worldSo, is this palatable for adults- perhaps. There are little Easter eggs of wtf is that in a children's movie for and a few weird moments such as a robot pondering death in a really creepy way.5.4 -- A younger crowd might give it a better score.

reviews.review_title: Too cliche and too much stereotypes
reviews.content:
One of the worst movies i ever seen too many clishes and stereotypes. And whats with the protagonist looks? Ok i mean she tries to differ from others, and be special and tries to fit , but her she looks dirty and a mess. I couldnt even look at her dirty hands and nails I mean you dont need to look like that to be different... the plot was meh and the message didnt get to me...
One of the worst boring movies ever.... i cant believe the good reviews...

I like this movie but it's really just Modern Day "Croods"
Kinda built up too much. Not a horrible movie and Maya Rudolph is in it so that always works for me. If you are a white Mom and have kids, just watch it...you'll know you'll cry.

Every moment is over the top, every set up to a joke has a payoff in .5 seconds, and then they bash you over the head with said joke until it's even less funny than before. Some cringeworthy slo-mo's and "epic" moments are mostly there for little kids watching this movie, but as a family movie I feel this could have been more thoughtful and cohesive. It felt all over the place emotionally and takes it self too seriously for the subject matter, in my opinion. The scatterbrained pacing gets old in about 5 minutes as it goes at about 1000 miles per hour all the time, with the exception of some sappy underwhelming slower moments. This film is not worth your time, again, in my opinion.

It's a huge disappointment, you watch the movie to try to understand the idea at the end, but what's the point!!!!! If you don't??? We consider family the most important thing in our lives, but not like that, no one laughs at this kind of movie, there is no a perfect family, we all have our problems but we still love each other, how dose I let my childrens to watch this farce, what impression will this movie leave on them ?

As I write this review on my smart Phone, I tap and swipe, whilst sitting on the toilet. According to latest movie I watched, that would be a big "NO NO"!I am a father of two, married and drive a family station wagon. I have a full time work and late one friday eavning, I watched "The Mitchells vs the Machines".I was tired, and started the movie on a single tought: Nothing better to watch, this will do...I had seen the title and watched parts of the trailer. But I was not ready for what was to come.It kind of reminded me of gumball, a series my oldest kid introduced me to. This kind of wierd machup of live videos, reality mixed up with cartoons. And I think it was a good thing, because it set me up to have an open mind. Prepare for anything and everything!And that is what this movie is all about. Slapstick jokes, your daily dose of internet, wierd stuff, emotions and warm fluffy feelings. It's like an Orchestra of what I can find on Youtube. Good or bad.But whitout the fuzz of having to deal with commersials or "reacts to".And with an open mind, I was hooked.It's not perfect, I'll give you that as an heads up.But I think it can be something for everyone in a family. From dad, mom, grandma and kids.I laughed and cried, both at the same time.It could be this stupid punchline or that slapstick joke combined with me beeing tired. But I really enjoyed every part of it.From all mentioned above, down to the core of the story: Family, and father/daughter relationship. What do you do as a father when your kid grows up, and you loose that way of having a good connection. When she was a kid, you were best pals. You could play games, laugh, be best buds and you could be the safe place when she was sad. "Love you dad, love you kiddo!"
Then she turned 15, and you went from beeing best dad to most embarassing dad.That is the core of this film, and that is what I loved most about it. A silly and stupid animated movie, making me laugh so hard I started crying. And also a deep story about a family, about a doughter and her dad, that also made me cry.Loved it, absolutley loved it.

IN A NUTSHELL:
This animated family adventure by Phil Lord and Chris Miller is completely adorable and came out of nowhere. I never saw any marketing for it and hadn't heard anything about it until two of my friends from high school recommended it to me on the Movie Review Mom Facebook group and I'm so glad they did! I absolutely loved it! We now have a contender for "Best Animation" for next year's Academy Awards.Here's the Netflix description: A quirky, dysfunctional family's road trip is upended when they find themselves in the middle of the robot apocalypse and suddenly become humanity's unlikeliest last hope.It's so much more than just that though. There's a lot to unpack such as lessons about family, self-confidence, Furbies, Artificial Intelligence, social commentary on our dependence on our cell phones, and so much more. The family-friendly flick was written and directed by both Michael Rianda and Jeff Rowe.THINGS I LIKED:
This hilarious movie is so inventive and fun. The comedic beats fly fast and furiously. Every frame is entertaining and creative.Abbi Jacobson voices Katie, the protagonist teen/film student and she does a fantastic job.For some reason, people wondered if Danny McBride would do a good job as a dad. The answer: yes, yes he does!Maya Rudolph voices the mom, Linda. Her character is super relatable and sweet. As a mom, I laughed at all of the things she does that I do.The rest of the voice talent is absolutely stellar and includes Academy Award-winning Olivia Colman, Eric Andre, married power couple Chrissy Teigen & John Legend, Conan O'Brien, and SNL stars Fred Armisen, Jay Pharoah, Beck Bennet, and Sasheer Zamata.Sony Pictures Animation has clearly learned from the many mistakes made in The Emoji Movie. The influence of The Lego Movie and Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse can be seen in the style of this film.The writers and directors also created Gravity Falls, a super funny animated TV show.People have been losing their minds that MIC Drop was used in the trailer.This movie would have been so much fun to watch in a movie theater because the audience's laughter would be contagious and energetic.All of the characters are super realistic, distinctive, and entertaining. The character design is really great.The background designs and set pieces are detailed, rich, and hilarious. The onscreen effects add another layer of richness and humor that is adorable and awesome. I love the look of a 2D cartoon animation added on top of a 3D animation, much like what we saw in Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse They look like the kind of effects Katie would add if she had made the movie.Tons of funny references to and social commentary on pop culture.The pacing flies at a brisk pace, except for in a few moments when old home movies are viewed to provide the sentimental foundation between the father and daughter.Keep watching during the end credits to see pictures of the film's creators with their families. Nice touch.THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:
I can understand why writer/director Michael Rianda would want to be in the movie, but his voice simply wasn't the right fit for the son, Aaron Mitchell. I suppose Michael was trying to dip into voice acting like director Brad Bird did with The Incredibles. Why didn't they get a child actor or someone who actually sounded like a little boy to voice the son? His voice was way too old sounding and it never had a comedic payoff.The resolution of the story is pretty predictable, even though there are a couple of false endings. Act 3 just keeps going and going.As soon as I saw the Furbies, I wondered what kind of product placement and merchandising deal the studio made with that company. Thankfully, none of the other pop culture items in the film seemed like blatant merchandising.TIPS FOR PARENTS:
This film is refreshingly wholesome and family-friendly! Yay!Family weirdness is celebrated. The entire film is family-centric and has a solid message about celebrating the unique differences and strengths in one another like in the movie The Incredibles
It's revealed quickly in the last scene that Katie is a lesbian.You can see my full review on my Movie Review Mom YouTube channel!

In "The Mitchells vs the Machines", Katie Mitchell (voiced by Abbi Jacobson) dreams of being a great film director (joining her icons on her version of Mount Rushmore!). She's about to travel to a west-coast film college when her dad Rick (Danny Mcbride) decides to cancel her air ticket and try to re-engage with her through one last epic road trip. Together with wife Linda (Maya Rudolph), dinosaur-mad son Aaron (director Michael Rianda) and cross-eyed pug Monchi (Doug the Pug!) they set off on their journey.But the world is set to change forever, as sentient operating system PAL (Olivia Colman) and her army of robots take over the world and prepare to launch human-kind into deep dark space. The Mitchell's, as the world's unlikeliest Avengers, appear to be the only ones available to prevent the evil plan!Positives:
In my review of the lamentable "Thunder Force", I commented that it failed my "six laughs test" for a comedy. I only laughed 3 times in the whole film. In contrast, this movie hammered home guffaw-generating lines and scenes about six times a minute! It's hilarious. It's one of those films (like the best Pixar ones) with so much hidden detail buried in every shot. You could watch it a dozen times and still find new hidden gags.This is a movie that is the perfect family film. A film that kids will love for the knockabout comedy and a film that adults will also fall in love with. This comes from three different angles:-- Excellent character development of the whole family. Katie feels like a fully rounded stroppy teen: she seems to be struggling with her identity (lesbian? - "It took me a while to figure myself out"); and she is struggling towards her personal goals despite the well-intentioned but destructive doubts that her rough-and-ready father keeps sowing. This feels like a journey that the family is on towards enlightenment, before it's too late.-- This is also a film with considerable emotional heft. It channels at times some of the best elements of the Toy Story films (most notably "Toy Story 3" with Andy's departure for college). (Any parents who have never experienced that joyous yet dreadful day when you drive your chicks to university or college for the first time: brace yourselves!)
-- It's a dream for film fans. Like "Ready Player One", it's populated with lots of fun movie easter-eggs scattered throughout. Katie's 'Mount Rushmore' by the way has Greta Gerwig, Céline Sciamma (from "Portrait of a Lady on Fire"), Lynne Ramsey and Hal Ashby as her directorial inspirations.And finally, it's a film for adults appreciative of some truly great satirical one-liners, including some razor-sharp zingers at 'big tech'. For example:"It's almost like stealing people's data and giving it to a hyper-intelligent AI as part of an unregulated tech monopoly was a bad thing"Negatives:
My only minor criticism - and its a debatable one - might be the running time of 113 minutes. It might be a little too long for younger kids' attention spans. A 90 minute, more condensed, movie might have ticked the 'perfection' box.Summary Thoughts: I don't normally "go" for animated films much. But this one is a different breed. An instant classic. It knocks you round the chops and forces your respect by being like no animated feature you've seen before.
